title: Linguine With Fourme D'ambert And Fresh Basil
Baked Alaska
description: Baked alaska was once a restaurant show stopper. A layering of spongecake, ice cream and meringue, it was presented on a tray and flambeed at the table to heat the covering of meringue so you had both warm and cold sensations as you ate it. But some restaurants serve it in individual portions, relying on a blowtorch back in the kitchen to caramelize the meringue. When Amanda Hesser brought this recipe to The Times in 1998, the pastry chef Stacie Pierce of the Union Square Cafe used espresso caramel ice cream instead of vanilla or chocolate and served a big ball of it on top of a tender chocolate souffle cake, rather than the traditional spongecake. The warm and cold effect is the same, and the flavors, sharper and distinct, come across as more mature.

title: Bitter Chocolate Pudding With Sauteed Bananas
Caramelized Salsify, Spatzle and Roasted Vegetable Broth
Quail With Grits, Apple and Celery Root
Poached Salmon With Lobster Potatoes And Veal Glace
Roasted Tomatoes Stuffed With Couscous, Chanterelles And Pine Nuts
Mushroom-Barley Soup
description: Soup made without meat or meat broth can be insipid. That's why most people think pea soup needs ham and mushroom-barley soup needs beef. But it's possible to make a satisfying, even hearty, vegetarian soup if you choose your ingredients carefully and extract every bit of flavor from them. Enter this mushroom-barley soup, a vegetarian dish with real body, texture and depth of flavor. The key ingredient here is dried porcini, which can be reconstituted in hot water in less than 10 minutes, giving you the best-tasting mushrooms you can find outside the woods and an intensely flavored broth that rivals beef stock. Don’t forget to toast the barley while really browning the mushrooms and carrots — it lends a deep warmth.

title: Fried Oysters With Creamy Tartar Sauce
recipe_yield: Six servings as an appetizer; two as a main course

title: Skate Wings With Cabbage And Spring Onions
Roasted Herbed Baby Chickens With Spicy Mango Barbecue Sauce
Broccoli With Vinegar And Hot Chili Oil
Baked Bluefish With Sweet Mustard Glaze
Roasted Sauerkraut And Bacon
ingredients: Sea salt and ground black pepper

title: Trout Papillote Style With Lemon And Olives
Pasta With Green Beans And Potatoes With Pesto
description: The most elegant pasta dish that Italian cooks have ever invented is astonishingly simple to make, especially now that pesto is made with a food processor instead of a mortar and pestle.

title: Penne Al Ortolano (Penne With Garden Vegetables)
description: Seasonal vegetables can be substituted for the ones in this recipe. Lightly steamed green beans, broccoli or cauliflower broken into small pieces work well in place of the zucchini; shredded spinach or other greens can take the place of the eggplant.

title: Corkscrew Pasta With Tomatoes And Basil
description: A simple tomato sauce, made from fresh or canned tomatoes, is the foundation for vast numbers of dishes, but it is also very good on its own. This recipe makes twice the amount of sauce needed for the dish. The rest can be refrigerated or frozen. Use fresh tomatoes, but only if they are very ripe, sweet and flavorful; about two pounds will do. Peel, seed and coarsely chop them before adding them to the saucepan. A pinch of sugar will help to accentuate the natural sweetness. Fresh tomatoes will need to cook about 10 minutes longer than canned.

title: Spaghetti With Garlic, Oil and Hot Red Peppers
description: This is the kind of quick, simple dish Italians often throw together after an all-night party or when spirits are flagging and an infusion of food is called for. Other types of long, thin pasta, like vermicelli, linguine or taglierini, may be substituted. If anchovies are omitted, adjust the salt in the sauce.

title: Gregory Cox's Warm Chicken And Vegetable Salad
Christopher Styler's Red Chard In Garlic Oil
Christopher Styler's Mussels Steamed Over Tomatoes And Fennel Seeds
Henry Meer's Curried Salmon With Lemon Grass En Papillote
Henry Meer's Basmati Rice With Golden Raisins
Chicken-Wing Salad With Toasted Garlic Vinaigrette
Carolina Chicken Bog
description: Here is a rich and peppery stew that hails from the coastal plains of the Carolinas. The name derives from the way in which the pieces of chicken sit in the pot, like hummocks in a bog. It has since spread across both North and South Carolina, according to Kathleen Purvis, the food editor of The Charlotte Observer in North Carolina. “Bog is one of those classic Carolina meals,” she said. “It’s clumpy, it’s delicious and you see it everywhere — at football games and Nascar race weeks alike.” Recipes for bog are as varied as the 146 counties of North and South Carolina. For ours, we turned to Robert Stehling, who runs the Hominy Grill in Charleston, S.C. Mr. Stehling’s bog features just about every part of the bird you can name, save feet and cockscombs. (Which would be worthy additions.) As outlined in the recipe here, the dish serves about eight hungry people, but the proportions can be adapted by anyone who can do a little fourth-grade math.

title: Strawberry Sauce
description: Ice cream sundaes, of course, find expression in their sauces, which provide layers of flavor and seismic contrasts in temperature and tone. To the category of vivid and bright belong fruit sauces, particularly those with a touch of acidity and a shake of vibrant color. Strawberries, raspberries, blueberries, sour cherries or pineapples -- sweet, just-ripe fruits cooked briefly with sugar -- will brighten vanilla's pallor (high-pectin fruits can often go it alone without cornstarch for body).

title: Butterscotch Sauce
description: Butterscotch sauce takes its character from brown sugar. The sauce contains cream and, yes, butter, and both strike round, rich, pleasingly burnished notes. Butterscotch will embrace a foundation ice cream flavor -- classics like chocolate, vanilla and coffee -- with abandon.

title: Hobo Pack of New Potatoes, Red Onion and Orange
Grilled Flank Steak
description: The simplest protein we know is our grandmother's marinated flank steak -- a recipe whose source she has long forgotten, but which we like to think was inspired by her childhood in Japan and her golden years in the South: pour a half-cup of bourbon, a half-cup of soy sauce and a half-cup of water into a freezer bag, add the steak, seal shut and marinate for two hours in the fridge.

title: French String Beans With Crushed Tomatoes
Strawberry tart in an almond nut crust
Mille et une feuilles with golden rasperries
Chocolate terrine (Chocolate mousse in chocolate sponge cake)
Risotto Venetian-style
ingredients: Salt and freshly ground black pepper

title: Creamy Vinaigrette
recipe_yield: 4 servings, enough for a total of 6 ounces greens

title: Goat Cheese Dressing
recipe_yield: 4 servings, enough for a total of 6 ounces greens

title: Strawberry Sorbet
ingredients: sugar, depending on sweetness of berries

title: Game Hens With Onions and Potatoes
Marvin Davis's Salad To Accompany Risotto
Pears in Red Wine With Fruit Compote
Braised Greens
description: Chicken stock, Sherry and red pepper flakes add flavor to this side dish that can be made with whatever hearty green is in season.

title: Figs with Creme Fraiche And Raspberry Coulis
Fig Tart With Honey-Vanilla Ice Cream

description: This is a home cook's take on a restaurant special, with shortcuts baked into the recipe. I learned the original at the elbow of Marc Murphy, the chef and an owner of Landmarc in Manhattan, and then adapted it for use in the home kitchen. (He grills. I pan-roast.) Brining gives the pork an incredible flavor, one amplified by the accompanying caramelized onions and apples. A drizzle of mock Bordelaise over the top elevates the whole enterprise: it's a meal for date nights and celebrations.
title: Cider-Cured Pork Chops

description: Classic bordelaise sauce, which can transform shoe leather into strip steak, is made with veal stock, demi-glace and time -- a lot of time. Here, though, you’ll use pan drippings from pork chops, simmering them with a red wine reduction until the two combine into an unctuous, rich sauce that flanks the old methods. Strain the whole thing, stir in a little butter and seasonings, and drizzle it over the pork chops. This takes most of a bottle of pinot noir, so choose the one you won’t mind finishing off in the kitchen yourself, alone with your heat and creativity.
title: A Cheat's Bordelaise Sauce
Salmon Fillet With Thyme And Roasted Tomatoes
Cauliflower, String Beans Capers and Tomatoes
Belgian Endive and Grain Mustard Salad
description: This is a fresh, tangy salad, loaded with sweet-sour flavor and given a good crunch by toasted hazelnuts. The bitter endive and peppery watercress complement each other beautifully, and it’s all tarted up with a citrusy dressing. It’s easy, and delicious.

title: Lentils With Bulgur And Herb Salad
Whole-Grain Crostini With Beans And Greens
Vietnamese Stir-Fried Vegetables With Chicken Or Shrimp
Grilled Meat Skewers With Bay Leaves
Warm Beet And String Bean Salad
ingredients: Sea salt and freshly ground pepper

Chilled Braised Apricots With Yogurt, Honey And Pistachios
Tomato and Horseradish Sauce
ingredients: bay leaf (if fresh basil is not available)
ripe tomatoes, about 3/4 pound, peeled and cut into 1/4-inch cubes
Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste

title: Stir-Fried Crabs With Black Bean Sauce
Veal With Artichoke, Black Olive And Mushroom Saute
ingredients: Kosher salt and freshly ground pepper

title: Braised Veal With Cardamom Spinach Puree
Braised Veal Shanks With Fava Bean Puree
Vanilla-Scented Rack Of Veal With Roasted Vegetables
ingredients: Kosher salt and freshly ground pepper

title: Breaded Veal Chop With Salad Of Young Greens
Scrambled Eggs, With Smoked Salmon in Brioche
You Will Get Better Soup
description: Ingredients that make eyes water and noses run turn out to be very useful in relieving cold and flu symptoms — so chicken soup made with hot, pungent additions works better than recipes that are more bland. That explains the fair amount of heat in this recipe, which can be assembled quickly, even by someone who is feeling pretty rotten (better yet, get someone to make it for you). Sip this slowly from a favorite mug on the couch, blankets tucked around you, and feel better soon.

title: Lattice Pastry
recipe_yield: Pastry for a nine-inch latticed-top pie

title: Passion Fruit Fool
description: There is something about the fragrant astringency of passion fruit, which when mixed with the bland, soft thickness of whipped heavy cream, makes one feel about as near to sensation heaven as it's possible to get at lunchtime.

title: Potato And Leek Soup With Crispy Masala Leeks
Mussels Steamed With White Wine And Curry Leaves
Ann and Eugene Patout's Crayfish Bisque
Chez Marcelle's Cajun Redfish Roulades Stuffed With Crayfish
Paul Prudhomme's Sweet Potato Pecan Pie
description: This recipe came to The Times in 1983 from Paul Prudhomme, the chef who put the cooking of Louisiana on the American culinary map. Like its traditional pecan pie cousin, this is very sweet, so serve it with a little Chantilly cream on top.

title: White Beans With Carrots and Roasted Garlic
Creamy White Bean And Carrot Soup With Rosemary Oil
ingredients: white beans and carrots with roasted garlic

title: Orange-Scented Black Beans With Roasted Poblano Peppers
Warm White Bean and Shrimp Salad With Lime Vinaigrette
Chicken Breasts And Garlic Balsamic Vinegar
ingredients: skinless, boneless chicken breasts, about 1 1/2 pounds

title: King Arthur Flour's Banana Crumb Muffins
King Arthur Flour's Tropical Chiffon Cake
Sole Judic (Baked sole wrapped in lettuce)
Spicy Hamburger With Red-Wine Sauce
description: Mr. Franey gives this American classic a Gallic twist. The recipe here can be prepared on a barbecue grill, in an oven broiler or even in a skillet. Whether you barbecue or broil, cook the patties about six inches from the heat source for about three minutes on each side, or until done as desired. If you are cooking on the stove top, use a heavy-gauge cast iron skillet. Cast iron sears extremely well when hot, but it has to be smoking hot before the meat is put in. Be sure the ventilation fan is on.

title: Green Sugar Snap Peas and Carrots With Fresh Mint
Northern-Style Dumplings
recipe_yield: 50 dumplings, or six to eight servings

title: Ecuadorean Shrimp Ceviche
ingredients: red bell pepper, halved, seeds removed
medium shrimp, peeled, deveined, halved lengthwise
kosher salt, plus more to taste

title: Banana Pese (Fried Green Plantains)
ingredients: green plantains, peeled, lightly scored and cut into 2-inch slices on the diagonal, peels reserved

title: Picalese (Pickled Chilies)
ingredients: small Spanish onion, peeled and thinly sliced
small carrot, peeled and thinly sliced

title: Polenta With Corn, Tomato And Red Onion Sauce
Thrill Of The Grill' Spice Paste
description: Schlesinger, this paste is wonderful with steaks or chicken. It also adds a husky note to veal chops. Rub four 8-ounce veal chops with the spice paste and refrigerate for 4 to 6 hours before grilling. Grill over hot coals until medium rare, about 4 minutes per side.

title: Tuscan Marinade
description: This marinade is particularly good with vegetables (see the following recipe) or with chicken paillard or flank steak. For chicken, pound four 6-to-8-ounce chicken breasts until they are 1/4 inch thick. Marinate in the refrigerator for 4 hours. Grill over hot coals until tender, about 2 to 3 minutes per side. For flank steak, marinate a 1 1/2-to-2-pound piece in the refrigerator for 8 hours. Grill over hot coals until medium rare, about 3 to 4 minutes per side.

title: Tuscan Grilled Summer Vegetables
ingredients: summer squash, cut into 2-inch-thick slices, lengthwise
patty pan squash, cut into 2-inch-thick slices
yellow bell pepper, seeded, deveined, cut into 2-inch-wide slices, lengthwise
red bell pepper, seeded, deveined, cut into 2-inch-wide slices, lengthwise
medium red onion, peeled, sliced into 1/2-inch-thick rounds

title: Korean Barbecue
description: This marinade is wonderful with pork chops, flank steak or chicken wings. For pork chops, marinate four 8-ounce chops in the refrigerator overnight. Grill over hot coals until medium-rare, about 5 minutes per side. For London broil or flank steak, marinate one 1 1/2-to-2-pound piece in the refrigerator for at least 8 hours. Grill over hot coals until rare, about 3 to 4 minutes per side.

title: Spice Island Marinade
description: This marinade imparts a pungent, Indian flavor to chicken, beef or ribs, but it works particularly well with tuna steaks or fish fillets. For four 6-to-8-ounce tuna steaks, marinate 1 1/2-inch-thick steaks in refrigerator for 4 hours. Grill over hot coals until rare, about 3 minutes per side.

title: Provencal Spice Rub
description: This rub from the south of France can be used with lamb or beef, but is particularly delectable with chicken and game. For chicken, marinate two 3-pound chickens, split in half, in the refrigerator for 6 hours. Place the chicken on the grill, skin side down. Cook over hot coals until the skin is charred, about 5 minutes. Turn the chicken and cover the grill. Continue cooking slowly until the meat is opaque at the bone, about 20 to 25 minutes. For duck breast, marinate two 10-to-12-ounce breasts in the refrigerator for 6 hours. Grill, skin side down, until charred, about 5 minutes. Turn the breasts and continue grilling until medium-rare, about 3 to 5 additional minutes.

title: Wolfgang Puck's Crisp Potato Galette With Scrambled Eggs
Tuna Or Swordfish With Onion Confit
Lamb Shank With Lima Beans In the French Style
Orzo and Lamb With Apples and Onions
Pineapple Salsa With 'killed' Onion
description: This salsa is warmed with chile and brightened by cilantro, but the dominant flavor is sweet fruitiness. It tames raw onions with a Turkish technique described as ''killing'' the onion: soaking it in salted water for about a half-hour to draw out some of its harshness. Serve this salsa with grilled meats.

title: Pico De Gallo
description: The strong flavors of scallions, cilantro and jalapeño complement the sweet juiciness of summer tomatoes in this traditional salsa. It makes the perfect accompaniment to grilled steak or tortilla chips.

title: Risotto With Broccoli Rabe and Acorn Squash
Broccoli-Rabe Pilaf With Pumpkin Seeds And Crispy Shallots
Potatoes and Broccoli Rabe Baked With Seasoned Oil
Marinated Fresh Sardines With Pickled White Beans
Monkfish With Wine Sauce and Mushrooms
Deep-Fried Soft-Shell Crabs in Pastella Batter
Chicken Roasted With Sour Cream, Lemon Juice And Mango Chutney
Purée of Peas and Watercress
recipe_yield: A side dish for 4 (or 2, with leftovers)

title: Couscous With Celery, Parsley and Red-Wine Vinegar
recipe_yield: A side dish for 4 (or 2, with leftovers)

title: Periyali's Greek Rice Pudding
description: This dish is called rizogalo, or Greek rice pudding. Though it is a simple dessert that is usually served cold, rizogalo is actually cooked the same way as risotto: the rice is simmered slowly and must be stirred constantly to massage the starch out of the grains and to attain a creamy, toothsome consistency.

title: Tony Garnier’s Gumbo
description: Here is a remarkable gumbo recipe that Eric Asimov scored off Tony Garnier, the bassist who plays behind Bob Dylan and is sometimes called his musical director, in 1998. It calls for all kinds of interesting meats, most of which can be substituted if you can't find them at the store, though the duck is tough to live without. Mr. Garnier picked up the recipe in the 1970s at Jay's Lounge and Cockpit in Cankton, Louisiana, a dive deep in Cajun country where the proprietor would keep a pot of gumbo simmering for when the music and the cockfighting were done for the night. ''I became interested in how to cook it, so I'd sneak back to the kitchen and ask questions,'' Mr. Garnier said. He refined the recipe for years. It is now at its apex.

title: Fresno Pork Roast With Hot Spiced Raisins
Bresaola, Goat Cheese, Arugula And Truffle Oil On Focaccia
Curried Chicken Salad With Slow-Roasted Tomatoes
Braised Fennel With Peppers and Olives
Souffle of Spinach And Goat Cheese
ingredients: Salt and freshly ground black pepper

title: Chicken Meunière
description: Traditionally, the term “meuniere” refers to fillets of sole that are floured and sauteed quickly, then finished with lemon juice, parsley and browned butter. But there’s no reason to be parochial about it. This is a fast, surprisingly elegant approach to boneless, skinless chicken breasts, or cutlets of pork, turkey or veal.

title: English Roast Fillet of Beef With Two Sauces
Turkey and Pork Meatballs With Tomato Sauce
Rack of Lamb With Parmesan Cheese
Chicken and Sausage Gumbo
ingredients: chicken, 2 1/2 pounds, cut into serving pieces
chopped or thinly sliced smoked sausage such as kielbasa (see note)

title: Boneless Quail Stuffed With Wild Rice and Mushrooms
Roast Rack of American Lamb Salad
Grilled California Goat Cheese on Toast
ingredients: round or rounds of goat cheese
bread rounds cut to the diameter of the cheese rounds, each about half an inch thick

title: Maida Heatter's Chocolate Cheesecake Brownies
recipe_yield: 16 square brownies or 32 bars or triangles
description: This delicious recipe comes from Maida Heatter, an expert on desserts.

title: Steamed Cod With Mesclun And Sweet Soy Dressing
Thai-Style Beef Salad With Mint
description: This salad, with Southeast Asian flair, takes mere minutes to make, even with cooking the beef. Its base is mesclun and a handful of flavorful, mild herbs, like parsley or mint. Because steak doesn't need any seasoning, cooking it takes only 10 minutes. You could substitute chicken, pork or shrimp. The vinaigrette that accompanies this salad is light but assertive, based not on olive oil but on a neutral-flavored oil like canola. I use relatively little oil, as its job is only to help the remaining dressing ingredients coat the greens. To this I add rice vinegar or lime juice, both of which are high in flavor but low in acidity. The vinaigrette is rounded off with mustard, shallots, and nam pla (Thai fish sauce) or soy sauce.

title: Baked Chicken Thighs With Ginger, Thyme And Yogurt
Dhanshak (Parsi Cornish Hens Braised In Spiced Pumpkin-Lentil Puree)
Masala Vangi (Eggplant Slices Smothered With Coconut-Spice Paste)
Chicken, Ham And Pea Potpies
ingredients: Italian 00 flour (see note) or all-purpose flour
granulated chicken bouillon or crushed bouillon cubes
diced ( 1/4 inch) ham or 1 additional cup diced chicken

title: Choco-Hoto-Pots
description: I can make no dietary defense for the choco-hoto-pots: they're just good. Think ponds of molten chocolate sauce enclosed in chewy-topped, dense chocolate sponge. By popular request, I paint the lily here by adding a sprinkle of white chocolate morsels.

title: French Lasagne
description: Nigella Lawson's recipe for savory baked croissant pudding, which goes by the name of French lasagne in her house, uses up stale croissants by having the cook split and stuff them with ham and cheese, sprinkle more cheese over the top and douse them in eggs beaten with garlic-infused milk. Your croissants need not be stale to achieve wonderfully eggy, cheesy results, but if they are fresh, consider leaving them on the counter to dry out first, or even toasting them briefly in the oven.

title: Cornmeal waffles
recipe_yield: Four to 14 waffles, depending on the size of the waffle iron

title: Cheese Waffles
recipe_yield: Four to 14 waffles, depending on the size of the waffle iron
description: One of the pleasures of waffle-making is, and always has been, the limitless flavors with which the waffles may be made and served: a blend of flours (such as whole-wheat and regular flour), cornmeal, various cheeses, nuts (such as pecans or hazelnuts), and so on.

title: Pecan Waffles
recipe_yield: Four to 14 waffles, depending on the size of the waffle iron

title: Whole-wheat waffles
recipe_yield: Four to 14 waffles, depending on the size of the waffle iron

title: Gaufres (French waffles)
recipe_yield: Four to 14 waffles, depending on the size of the waffle iron

title: Pork And Pozole With Chipotles
ingredients: pork shoulder, trimmed of excess fat and cut into chunks

title: Fricassee of Squid and Potatoes

title: Roasted Garlic
recipe_yield: About 60 cloves or 1/2 cup mashed garlic

title: Roasted Garlic Jam
description: Garlic can be subtle and sweet, or it can be a big bully with acrid undertones. Its behavior depends on how it's cooked and in what company. Here, it cozies up with lemon juice, cayenne and parsley, blending fast into a zippy, soft topping for bruschetta, pizza or your favorite grilled meat.

title: Roasted Garlic, Tomato and Olive Salsa
Garlic Broth With Lobster or Chicken
Garlic Custard With Shrimp And Tomato Broth
Chicken With 40 Cloves of Garlic And Garlic Bread
Fettuccine With Fennel And Shiitake Mushrooms
Crown Roast of Lamb With Burghul Pilaff
Pork and Mango Salsa Burrito
recipe_yield: 4 or 5 tortillas, enough for 2 very hungry people

ingredients: large ripe mango, peeled and flesh cubed

Farfalle With Asparagus And Wild Mushrooms
Alfred Portale's Summer Squab Salad With Couscous and Curry
Tomato-Vegetable Sauce

fresh pepper, plus more to taste
small celery roots, trimmed, peeled and chopped
cabbage leaves, blanched until wilted, drained, heavy center rib removed

title: Lara's Yogurt Balls
ingredients: whole-milk yogurt, sheep's milk, if possible

Clam loaf
ingredients: Clam sauce with Pernod or Ricard

title: Clam sauce with Pernod or Ricard
Warm Lamb and New Potato Salad
Spaetzle

title: Pommes Natures (Steamed potatoes)
ingredients: new red-skinned potatoes, about 1 to 1 1/4 pounds

title: Manhattan Clam Chowder with Hake and Chorizo
description: This recipe dresses up the chowder with chorizo and pan-fried hake, an inexpensive cousin to cod.

title: Chicken Livers, With Cumin and Coriander
Salmon and Crème Fraîche On Black-Bread Toasts
Roasted Guinea Hen
recipe_yield: Enough for 2 for dinner and lunch the next day

title: Haricots Verts With Walnuts and Walnut Oil
Sweet-Potato Tian With Spiced Shrimp and Prosciutto
Oven-Dried Tomato Tian With Creamy Lima Beans And Goat Cheese
ingredients: 1-inch-square bread cubes, from good country-style bread

title: Pasta, Potato and Green-Bean Tian With Basil Cream and Parmesan
Southwestern Chicken Pie With Cheddar-Spoon-Bread Crust
Ken Hom's Shrimp With Cashew Nuts
Bombay Leg Of Lamb With Yogurt And Lime
Rhineland Sauerbraten
description: “Braising is a cooking method that is little understood and much neglected,” Mimi Sheraton wrote in The Times in 1983. “The long, slow, moist process fills the house with warm scents of simmering meats, vegetables and herbs and yields in robust main courses that include rich sauces and gravies to be aborbed by potatoes, rice or noodles. And because the moisture tenderizes the meat, even the least expensive cuts gradually take on savory overtones.” She accompanied her article with this luscious sauerbraten, which benefits greatly from larding the meat with bacon or salt pork, and is even better the day after it is prepared.

title: Pork Braised In Milk And Cream
ingredients: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

title: Stewed Spicy Chicken With Lemongrass And Lime
Tsuni's Chicken Salad Oriental
ingredients: medium fennel bulb to yield 1 cup thinly sliced

title: Asparagus With Roasted Red Pepper Salsa
Endives et poulet au gratin (Endives and chicken au gratin)
Baked Endives with Parmesan Cheese (Endives au Parmesan)
Endives with Blue-cheese Dressing and Walnuts
Tapioca Zabaglione Custard With Fresh Berries
Philippe Bertineau's Chilled Heirloom Tomato Soup
Chicken la Tulipe
description: Jonathan Reynolds brought this recipe to The Times in 2000, from the New York restaurant La Tulipe. He thought it a perfect dish for a man to cook for a woman. (Whether that is also true for men cooking for men and women cooking for women, he said he didn’t know, so we tested it out: It does.) The morels and Cognac are wildly sophisticated additions to what otherwise might be a plain roasted chicken, making the dish an easy, stylish win for newish cooks interested in making an impression on a sweetheart or someone who might become one. Make the cooking “appear effortless,” Mr. Reynolds wrote. “Pour things from a great height. Think Fred Astaire, not one of those grunting tennis players.”

title: Turkey Steaks With Mushrooms and Mustard Seeds
Julienne of Carrots With Snow Peas
Vegetarian Chili With Corn Bread Topping
description: The idea behind this spicy, all-vegetable chili is ease: It’s easily made on a weekend, a meditative wintry afternoon in the kitchen, chopping and stirring. Then, on a weeknight made even shorter by commuting and homework, concoct an easy corn bread topping, spread it on the chili and bake it for a while. It’s healthy, filling food.

title: Spiced Beef in Red Wine
description: There is nothing to stop you from serving spiced beef in red wine at a dinner party, but proper cooking should not be undertaken only for company. I make a batch of the beef and, when it is cool, bag it up in single portions and put it in the freezer. It makes a great warming supper for nights when you are lazing on a sofa watching television. Just because it's Wednesday, you need not have to resort to a bagel or grilled cheese for dinner.

title: Reindeer, Venison or Beef With Mushrooms and Berry Sauce
Oaxacan Yellow Mole Filling
description: Oaxaca is the place where they invented mole sauce, "that perfect specimen of Mexican cooking," according to Ana M. de Benitez in "Pre-Hispanic Cooking." This is also where the natives carve wonderful mythological creatures and eat their tamales steamed in banana leaves (unlike anywhere else in Mexico).

title: Blanquette De Veau
description: A bourgeois veal stew in cream sauce from Burgundy. This straightforward blanquette recipe comes from the ''Balthazar Cookbook."

title: Chicken Tagine With Olives And Preserved Lemons
Lamb Tagine With Baby Artichokes And Mint
Bourbon-Pecan Chicken
description: This is a 1990 recipe from Regina Schrambling that was appended to an article about the role alcohol can play in a home cook's kitchen. It's terrific.

title: Sake Salmon With Black Bean Sauce
Tia Rosa and Ruth Eichner's Sweet-and-Sour Carrots
Julia Alvarez's Pudin de Pan (Bread Pudding)
Veal With Paprika and Sour Cream
Emince de Veau a la Moutarde (Veal strips with mustard)
Corn Risotto With Okra And Shiitake Mushrooms
Veal Loin With Artichokes And Spinach With Paprika Sauce
Cold Spiced Chicken And Zebra-Tomato Salad
Cold Melon Soup With Tarragon and Dry Sherry
Sea Bass With Tomato Coulis, Basil and Asparagus
Fillets of Lamb With Fresh Thyme
Broiled Cornish Hens With Lemon And Balsamic Vinegar
Salt Cod Fritters
description: Salt cod, often called by the fish's Spanish name, bacalao, or some variation, is still popular, but not because salting is the most efficient way of preserving fish; about a hundred years ago, freezing claimed that honor. Salting completely transforms cod's flavor and texture, allowing all sorts of dishes that are not possible with fresh cod or, for that matter, with anything else. At least not with such character.

title: Salt Cod Mousse
description: The most familiar preparation of salt cod to most Americans is brandade de morue, or salt cod mousse. For this, the cooked cod is best pounded with a big mortar and pestle to a very creamy consistency. For busy cooks, the recipe here calls for the job to be done in a food processor, but the texture is not quite the same. Purists willing to use a little muscle power will be rewarded with the best results.

title: Langue de Boeuf aux Lentilles (Beef tongue with lentils)
Jumbo Shells Stuffed With Ricotta Filling
Manicotti With Cheese Filling and Bolognese Sauce
Bolognese Sauce (An Italian tomato and meat sauce)
Cooked Meat and Tomato Sauce Italian Style
Smoked Turkey And Avocado Sandwiches With Tangy Corn Relish
Salmon, Chicken or Veal Chop Milanese
Tripes a la mode de Caen (Baked tripe with Calvados)
Penelope Casas's callos a la Madrilena (Tripe Madrid-style)
recipe_yield: 10 or more main-course servings; 24 appetizer servings

title: Chicken Breasts Stuffed With Wild Mushrooms
Dutch Baby
description: The term “Mardi Gras,” which in French means Fat Tuesday, refers to the centuries-old tradition of using up all the fat in the house before the austere six-week period of Lenten fasting starts. Strictly observed, Lent meant consuming no animal products whatsoever. Except in the Mediterranean countries of Europe, where olive oil was produced, animal fats were generally used for frying. Pancakes, crepes, fritters, crullers and waffles, sometimes consumed competitively in vast quantities, became traditional foods for Mardi Gras celebrations. A large puffy pancake called a Dutch baby fits right into the ritual. But these pancakes are excellent for breakfast, brunch, lunch and dessert with dinner throughout the year.

title: Lemon Grass, Chili and Mint Steaming Liquid
Chicken Rolls Stuffed With Rice, Lemon and Herbs

title: Salmon and Shiitakes Wrapped In Lettuce Leaves

title: Scallops With Leeks, Mushrooms And Potatoes
ingredients: Chardonnay, lemon and herb steaming liquid

title: Peach Ice Cream
description: This easy ice cream is meant to evoke hazy memories of a summer spent luxuriating on a front porch, cold glass in hand, waiting as your ice cream maker does the churning work for a late-afternoon treat. Use the best peaches you can find — the flavor of this depends directly on the fruit. You can also use mangoes or strawberries, or other stone fruits. Use your imagination, but let the ice cream maker do most of the work.

title: Potato Salad With Smoked Chicken and Corn on the Cob
Spring Rolls With Hawaiian Shrimp
description: For a leaner alternative, green leaf lettuce can be used instead of egg roll wrappers. If using lettuce, follow all instructions except for frying. Chill briefly before serving.

freshly ground pepper, plus more to taste

title: Shrimp Jambalaya
description: The chef Paul Prudhomme's unassailably authentic seafood jambalaya requires two hours of cooking time, apart from the preparation. This version stands up reasonably well, and cuts down the preparation and cooking time to just under 60 minutes.

title: Riz Creole
description: This Creole rice was intended to be served with jambalaya, but works well with any number of dishes. It is simple to make, and once mastered will become a go-to dish.

Anna Teresa Callen's Pizza alla Cozze

recipe_yield: 1 pie or 16 small individual soufflé dishes

title: Oxtail Braised With Tomato and Celery (Coda Alla Vaccinara)
description: Ms. Hesser brought us this recipe for the classic Roman stew back in 2002 after she visited Rome with her family.

title: Grilled Tuna, Tomato And Onion Topping
Eggplant Caviar And Parsley-Mint Salad Topping

Flounder Saute With Asparagus And Crab Vinaigrette
Zucchini and Cherry Tomatoes With Garlic
Pasta Frittata
description: This dish is one recipe calling for leftover pasta that is actually worth planning for. It's portable, it's endlessly versatile, and it's practically foolproof. Substitute almost any cheese for the Parmesan (or leave it out altogether) and toss in any cooked vegetable or meat. Make it your own.

This is a not-very-sweet, very grown up chocolate mousse, and it is quite easy to make. If you prefer the idea of a chocolate orange mousse, substitute Cointreau. Rum works well, too. Or you could use coffee in place of the alcohol. In any case, eating it is an example of living well.
title: Chocolate Cherry Mousse
Gateau Reine de Saba
description: Julia Child wrote that the Gateau Reine de Saba was the first French cake she ever ate. My version is a bit simpler to make than hers. I melt the chocolate with liquid, and I use all ground almonds rather than the traditional mixture of flour and almonds. I like my Reine de Saba to be slightly more like pudding and voluptuously melting. As "Reine de Saba" is French for Queen of Sheba, this seems entirely fitting. It also makes this cake eminently suitable for those who are gluten-intolerant. A little of this cake goes very far. You can easily get 12 slices out of this cake, so each person isn't consuming a huge amount of sugar. But to be defensive is to end on the wrong footing. A cake this good does you good, both body and soul.

title: Sautéed Scallops Stuffed With Basil
description: Use the biggest scallops you can find for this recipe. They’re easier to butterfly and more forgiving to cook (meaning that they take longer to overcook, which is the worst thing you can do here). If you happen to cut the scallops all the way through, sandwich them back together around the basil; scallops have enough gelatin to more or less stick to themselves. This recipe can also be made with pesto, but homemade pesto takes a bit of time, and the scallops cook in no time at all, so the pesto sort of slows the recipe down. A whole basil leaf serves the same purpose and is much quicker. Serve the scallops on a bed of mixed greens. Deglazing the pan with lemon juice is a nice touch; the warm dressing on cool greens is a treat. And you can use wine, stock, soy sauce or any number of other liquids to play around with the flavor of the dish as you like.

title: Montreal Bagels
description: As with most ethnic foods, bagels are prepared differently from city to city, community to community. But the special appeal of Montreal bagels draws even those accustomed to the New York variety.

title: Deep-Dish Mushroom Pie
recipe_yield: Eight appetizers or six main courses

title: Three Little Asparagus Soups For Spring
description: The most daunting aspect of serving three asparagus soups is finding 18 little bowls. But unless you're having Nathan Lane to dinner, who cares if they match? Coffee cups, old-fashioned glasses, mugs, pairs of cupped hands -- all are fine.

title: Pineapples Victoria
description: This creme brulee is much easier to make than most, and because it is poured over the top of the pineapple, it is more forgiving.

title: Cream Puffs with Tarragon Chicken Hash
Poitrine de volaille pochee (Poached chicken breast)
Persimmon Gelato With Rum
description: The rum is really what puts this persimmon gelato over the top, because it then tastes like the creamy apotheosis of rich frozen rum. For this recipe, you’ll need Fuyu persimmons, which are more forgiving than their Hachiya counterparts. When whisking in the eggs, watch the heat. Keep it low. You don’t want them to curdle.

title: Pintade au Vin Rouge (Guinea hen in red wine sauce)

Irish Oatmeal Brulee With Dried Fruit And Maple Cream

title: Seared Salmon Fillets With Roasted Fennel And Balsamic Lentils
Chicken Fricassee With Vermouth
description: This is an elegant, velvety take on a traditional skillet-supper, perfect with a mound of fluffy white rice. Cooking this fricassee with the aperitif known as dry vermouth instead of the more traditional white wine results in a slightly sweeter and more aromatic sauce than you would ordinarily get. (White vermouth is composed of, among other things, white wine plus a bit of sugar, herbs and plants and, at times, the bark of trees.) But white wine will work as well.

title: Paupiettes De Sole Au Vermouth (Rolled Sole Fillets In Vermouth Sauce)
Sauce Vinaigrette Au Vermouth (Vermouth Vinaigrette For Salads)
Pork Chops, With Green Peppercorn Sauce
Sesame Noodles With Shrimp and Corn
Pork Meatballs With Rosemary
description: Volumes have been written about ''new'' combinations of sauces and flavors for the delight of those who dine on pasta. We find this laudatory and have ourselves introduced ''new'' flavors for pasta. There are times, however, when we still have a slight craving for one or another of the basics, such as spaghetti with meatballs.

title: Classic Deviled Eggs
description: This recipe is adapted from ''U.S.A. Cookbook," a tribute to classic all-American dishes, written by Sheila Lukins, a co-author of the Silver Palate cookbooks that were popular in the 80s and 90s. There are no newfangled ingredients here - no lemongrass or curry or pesto - just eggs, mustard, mayonnaise, a dash of Tabasco and a festive sprinkle of paprika (if you're feeling fancy, garnish with chives). They are basic, but spectacular, and always a welcome addition to the picnic table.

title: North Carolina-Style Pulled Pork Barbecue
ingredients: soft rolls or slices of white bread

ingredients: Freshly ground white pepper to taste

title: Crispy Rice Crepe Napoleons With Raspberry Red-Chili-Pepper Sorbet

Passion-Fruit Salad With White-Pepper Ice Cream
Fromage Blanc-Lemon Grass Sorbet
description: This recipe, adapted from the restaurant Vong in New York, strikes a surprising balance. The fromage blanc is tangy and blunt; the lemon grass rounds out the edges and showers it with a floral, herbal aroma that lingers in your mouth. It is 20 minutes of your time for a complex endnote to a meal.

title: Strawberry-Moscato Sorbet
description: This sorbet is an easy, elegant finish to a summer dinner. A good sorbet should taste like an extraction of its main flavor, and nothing else. It should be gutsier than ice cream, and purer; there is no custard to compete with. But while sorbets are easy to make, they are also unforgiving, and require the best fruit you can find. For this recipe, you’ll want to use the sweetest, ripest strawberries available, as the fruit’s flavor is mostly the point here.

title: Yogurt Cheese With Horseradish And Chives

This savory-sweet stir-fry, known as
title: Shaking Beef
Crown Roast of Lamb
description: The crown rib roast is one of the most festive and serviceable cuts of meat, beautifully proportioned and wieldy, with luscious, lean red meat at the chop end tapering off into rustic, fatty and crispy rib bits at the bone end, with a built-in handle to facilitate gnawing.

title: Smoked Trout Salad With Candied Kumquats

title: Poached Blood Oranges in Clementine Ratafia
Grapefruit-and-Meyer-Lemon Marmalade
description: This recipe came to The Times from June Taylor, the impresario of preserving whose jams and jellies, made in her workshop in Berkeley, Calif., are esoteric works of art. For this sweet-tart concoction, you’ll need a jelly bag, used to draw pectin from the fruit, which can be found online or at your local kitchen supply store (you can also make your own out of muslin.) The recipe is for marmalade devotees who want a surprise: you’ll cut the Meyer lemon into chunks, so when you eat the marmalade, you get a burst of lemon, a bit of culinary sunshine.

title: Cool Soba Noodles With Sweet Soy Broth
White Beans With Squid And Broken Noodles
Bobby Flay's New York Strip Steak With Horseradish-Mint Glaze
Cauliflower and Broccoli Salad With Ginger Vinaigrette
Burnt-Sugar Ice Cream With Butterscotch Sauce
Roast Chicken With Cumin, Honey and Orange
description: An easy way to give roast chicken some character is to baste it with flavorful liquid. Contrary to conventional wisdom, this does nothing to keep the bird moist. Even a very lean bird remains moist as long as it isn't overcooked. But the liquid adds flavor to the skin and creates a ready-made sauce that can be spooned over the chicken as you serve it.  If you add some sugar or other sweetener to the basting liquid, the bird gains a mahogany color that you have to see to believe. As it heats, the sugar caramelizes, becoming thicker and stickier and turning the chicken's skin crisp and gorgeous. The result is not overly sweet, because caramelized sugars have a bitter, complex component. I prefer honey to sugar and like to combine it — as I do here — with orange juice and ground cumin, which together add acidity and even more complexity. This aromatic mix creates pan juices that can be spooned over rice or sopped up with bread.

title: Sautéed Chicken With Green Olives and White Wine
description: In 2004, Mark Bittman introduced this recipe to readers of The Times as part of a spirited defense of dark-meat chicken parts. That defense reaches peak awesomeness here, with the chicken browned and slightly braised, with olives and walnuts, and a slight acid zing from the wine and lemon.

title: Stir-Fried Shrimp With Snow Peas and Ginger
description: In 2005, Julia Moskin wrote an excellent article about woks, the best sort for American kitchens (a 14-inch heavy-gauge carbon-steel wok with a flat bottom) and how to season it. This recipe, adapted from Grace Young's book, "The Breath of a Wok," ran alongside it. It is simple, fresh and fast. It cooks in under 5 minutes, so start your pot of rice as you clean the shrimp and chop the ginger, garlic and scallions.

title: Salt-Baked Snapper with Ice Wine Nage
Twice-Cooked Lamb
description: These lamb ribs are a specialty of Kashmir called tabak maaz. The ribs undergo a curious braise-then-brown process which, though uncommon, makes perfect sense. The meat is made tender by braising, then browned with fresh spices and oil (or, in this case, butter). The result is the flavor of braising with the crispness of sautéing, an unbeatable combination.

title: Calamari Rings With Green Chili Mayonnaise
Penne With Tomatoes, Basil and Two Cheeses
Fusilli With Tomatoes, Eggplant and Pine Nuts
Spaghetti With Tomato and Red Pepper Sauce
Polenta
description: To make the "candy"; that my sister and I loved, use a stainless-steel pot with a copper bottom. After you have removed the cooked polenta, the inside of the pan will be coated with mush. Put it over high heat for 2 to 3 minutes and gently peel the crust that forms away from the sides of the pan. "Only a devoted mother will do this," says mine.

title: Ravioli With Spinach
recipe_yield: Six to eight servings as antipasto, about 100 ravioli
description: My aunt would save leftover meat in the freezer until she had enough to make the filling. The dough should be made a day in advance, and the filling and the sauce can be made then. Allow about 2 hours to assemble and plan on putting them together several hours before cooking so they have time to dry.

title: Pumpkin (or Sweet Potato) In Brown Sugar Syrup

recipe_yield: 3 to 4 servings as a lunch course with a simple green salad

Roast Haddock Fillet With Scalloped Potatoes
Roast Fillet of Beef With Wild Mushroom Sauce
Mashed Potatoes With Garlic and Onions
Magret de Canard With Colonel Hawker Sauce
description: Colonel Hawker is said to have been Wellington's fowling officer. His recipe was given to me by my friend, the late Angus Cameron.

title: Veal Stew With Pineapple And Tomato
Italian Roast Potatoes
description: These potatoes are beloved by children and adults alike, and they are very easy to make. Just cube the potatoes (don't bother to peel) and tumble them into a pan. Pour on the olive oil, sprinkle the oregano, peel the garlic cloves (you don't even have to do that if you're pushed for time), mix everything together and stick the dish in the oven. Serve alongside some lamb chops and a simple salad, or just the salad.

title: Braised Ribs of Beef With Horseradish Dumplings
Osso Buco With Anchovies and Sage
Winter Stew of Braised Lamb, Red Onions And Macaroni
Shad Fillets With Red Pepper And Saffron Sauce
Shad Fillets Braised With Wild Mushrooms And Tomatoes
Polenta With Italian Peppers and Mushrooms
Chicken Salad With Lime and Red Onions
Bacon-Topped Meatloaf Burgers
description: Instead of turning a meatloaf into a red-centered burger-loaf, why not turn a burger into a tender, juicy meatloaf patty? You get the inimitable meatloaf flavors of beef laced with ketchup and onion but in a far more delectable form. Simply broil the burgers until they are just past purple on the inside, and seared mahogany brown on the outside. This takes about five minutes — 55 minutes less than a traditional meatloaf. Put the patties on a potato bun and bite in. The meat is juicy enough to soak the roll, and is flavored in that meatloaf manner — brawny yet barely sweet, porky from the bacon, aromatic with herbs, onion and garlic, all commingled with a deep, beefy flavor. Excellent!

title: Salmon Burgers
description: If you finely grind part of the salmon, it will bind the rest, which can be coarsely chopped to retain its moisture during cooking. Some bread crumbs keep the burger from becoming as densely packed as (bad) meatloaf. This approach, along with a few simple seasonings, produce delicious burgers in not much more time than it takes to make one from ground chuck. The only real trick is to avoid overcooking. Whether you sauté, broil or grill this burger, it's best when the center remains the color of … salmon. Two or three minutes a side usually does the trick.

title: Cucumber Spaghetti, Strawberry Purée and Crushed Olives
Pitas Stuffed With Lamb Burgers and Peppers
Farfalle With Pesto Sauce, String Beans and Potatoes
Skate With Brown Butter, Honey And Capers
Nicole Kaplan's Gougères (Served at Eleven Madison Park)
Pipiruchkas Reyenadas De Keso (Peppers stuffed with Cheese)
Ma-Po Tofu (Simmered Tofu With Ground Pork)
description: I have long enjoyed stir-fried tofu creations like ma-po tofu, a classic dish from Sichuan. But I found making them difficult. This version is easy and quick.

title: Braised Chicken With Ginger and Chestnuts
Goat's Milk Cheese, Buttered Brown Bread And Salted Onion
Junipero Gibson With Pickled Red Onion
Red Lentils and Chili Sauce With Quinoa
Corned Beef
description: Molly O'Neill brought this recipe to The Times in 2000. It calls for brining the meat for 8 to 12 days, but you can cheat. Even a few days will yield tender results.

title: Horseradish Sauce for Corned Beef or Brisket
Maple Mustard Pork On a Bed of Mashed Sweet Potatoes
Chicken Bouillabaisse With Chorizo and Clams
Squid, Tomato And Roasted Poblano Stew

Venison Medallions With Blackberry Sage Sauce
ingredients: Coarse salt and freshly ground pepper to taste

title: Dried Fava Beans With Bitter Greens
Croque Monsieur
description: In Italy, bricklayers and plutocrats alike eat the same thing for lunch: panini, sandwiches layered with meat and cheese and flattened between two searing griddles. Today they're almost as common as cappuccino in America, albeit much cheaper and easier to make. One affordable panini press, and you're on the fast track to the perfect party food.

title: Deviled Chicken Thighs
description: In cooking, the term ''deviled'' has several meanings, but it most often implies a preparation with a sharp flavor, most often derived from mustard, vinegar, cayenne or other chiles. In this dish, you don't need vinegar, because there is plenty of acidity in Dijon mustard. Nor, strictly speaking, do you need cayenne (and I omit it when cooking for children); the taste is strong without it.

title: Sage Chicken In A Fried Potato Crust
Stir-Fried Beef With Black Beans And Onions
Pizza With Tomatoes, Onions And Olives

title: Pizza With Arugula, Corn And Bacon

title: Grilled Skirt Steak With Mixed Peppers

description: Roast a chicken and you know you have a comfortable meal. Alter that a little by butterflying the chicken, a surprisingly simple task that can be carried out with a pair of kitchen scissors, and you have a quick dinner that carries with it the casual air of barbecue, without the bother. Here, buttermilk, which is usually associated with fried chicken, helps to tenderize the chicken and conveys the aromatics: you really get the full value of the rosemary, pepper and garlic. If you want to substitute maple syrup for the honey, you can. Best of all, you can leave the marinating bird in the fridge for up to two days; thus, it gets more tender and you know you have a dinner that needs no more than to be popped into the oven.
title: Buttermilk Roast Chicken
Strawberry Sour Cream Streusel Cake
description: This strawberry streusel cake is the perfect end to a summer meal. But here's the interesting thing: Eat it slightly warm and it's dessert; let it get cold, and it makes a great coffee cake for breakfast the next day. The cake is slightly tricky to assemble, and at some point it may look like a mess. But everything comes together in the pan as it bakes, resulting in a tender, fragrant cake. This isn’t a recipe to embark on at the end of a long workday. Save it for the weekend.

title: Portuguese Kale-and-Salt-Cod Chowder

kale, stemmed, rinsed and coarsely chopped to make 6 cups

title: Fresh Cod Baked With White Beans And Linguica

title: Raw Beet Salad
description: This is a beet recipe for someone who is skeptical of their earthy, rooty flavor. Uncooked beets are less sweet and earthy than they are when boiled or roasted. This is a messy affair, so peel and grate them near the sink.

title: Jerusalem Artichoke Fritters
description: The fritters in this recipe are almost better cold than hot, making them ideal to prepare ahead of time. Jerusalem artichokes — a knobby, sweetly versatile vegetable — require no peeling, only a good scrub with a stiff vegetable brush, cutting down on prep time. You’ll grate them into a bowl with the rest of your ingredients, season to taste and fry over medium heat until they’re golden brown. Serve them with a sour cream dipping sauce, and your guests will clamor for more.

title: Scallops With Artichokes And Jerusalem Artichokes

dried tangerine peel (sold in Asian markets)

Bouquet garni of thyme, bayleaf and tarragon

scallions, white and light-green parts, thinly sliced
