Shad and Shad Roe With Mushrooms
Classic Onion Soup With Veal Stock
Braised Sea Bass With Veal Glaze
Alaskan Halibut And Salmon Gefilte Fish Terrine
Grilled Duck Breast With Pepper Jelly Glaze
Smothered Greens
ingredients: assorted greens -- like mustard, broccoli rape, collard, kale, turnip -- stemmed, washed and chopped

title: Strawberries With Pink Peppercorn Sauce
ingredients: strawberries, washed and stemmed (1 cup diced, the rest sliced)
cod or other fillet, in two pieces
title: Simplest Steamed Fish
description: If you have forgotten how delicious a great fillet of fish can be, try this: Steam it, with nothing on it. Drizzle it with olive oil and lemon juice. Sprinkle it with coarse salt. Eat.

ingredients: nectarines, pitted, peeled and cut into 1-inch chunks (about 3 large nectarines)
title: Blackberry Nectarine Crisp
description: This recipe came to The Times in 2003 from Rebecca Charles of Pearl Oyster Bar, an outpost for Maine coastal cooking on Cornelia Street in Greenwich Village. It is easy to whip up on a summer day when company is coming and there’s lots to get done. "Use the blackberries more as an accent," she said at the time. "'The berries'll bleed out all this fabulous inky color."

title: Rice With Edamame
description: This dish is called mame gohan, the Japanese version of rice and beans. The beans are simmered in dashi seasoned with mirin and light soy sauce, and then the same cooking liquid is used for the rice. Before serving, the beans and rice are folded together, with a light dusting of salt and black sesame seeds.

title: Cuban Pork Tenderloin With Chimichurri Sauce
Grilled Swordfish With Smoked Tomato Salsa
Blackberry Ice Cream With Candied Lemon Zest
Vegetables and Shrimp With Gado Gado
Chinese Steak With Asparagus and Rice
Provençal Salmon
description: In 1998, Mark Bittman and Katy Sparks, then chef of Quilty's in Manhattan, developed this easy recipe for salmon encrusted with fennel seeds, rosemary and orange zest. It's a simple though sophisticated twist on weeknight salmon.

title: Ulli's Scallops And Mache With Pumpkinseed Oil
Octopus Salad With Crispy Vegetables
ingredients: extra virgin olive oil, or more to taste
chopped basil, plus more for garnish

title: Spaghetti With Octopus Braised In Red Wine
Chicken-Tarragon Pot Pie
description: This recipe, which is adapted from “Julia and Jacques at Home” by Julia Child and Jacques Pépin and was featured in a New York Times article about roast chicken, makes delicious use of leftovers (it would be excellent with the Thanksgiving turkey remainders as well). It is rich, but packed with vegetables. You can substitute dried tarragon for fresh, but use less than a tablespoon, and season to taste.

title: Chinese Chicken Salad
description: Here's a bright and flavorful way to use up leftover cold chicken that can be thrown together in about 20 minutes.

title: Calf's Liver With Pancetta And Marsala
Crunchy Pork Chops With Baby Spinach Salad
ingredients: pork chops, with bone, trimmed of fat

title: Pork (Or Chicken) Stewed In Coconut Milk
ingredients: unsweetened coconut milk, or as needed

title: Chicken With Mixed Mushrooms And Cream
Braised Pork Chops With Five-Spice And Orange Peel
Black Cod With Lemon And Grains Of Paradise
Crab Meat Pasta
ingredients: spaghetti, linguine or pasta of choice

title: Soft-Shell Crabs With Corn And Black-Bean Salsa
Curried Carrot And Red Snapper Chowder
Brown Sugar Frozen Yogurt And Berries
Fred's Chocolate-Pecan Cookies
description: This recipe, an adaptation of a popular cookie served at Fred's restaurant in Barney's New York, the Madison Avenue department store, is rich, chewy and dotted with crunchy pecans. If you're into the salty-sweet thing (who's not?), add a sprinkle of flaky sea salt a few minutes before the cookies are done baking.

title: Kale Soup With Potatoes and Sausage
Escarole Stuffed With Raisins, Walnuts And Anchovies
recipe_yield: Four side-dish or two main-dish servings

title: Bulgur and Bow Ties With Mushrooms and Beef
Roast Pheasant With Cabbage and Bacon
Salmon on a Bed Of Creamy Cabbage
Ginger-Roasted Apples With Vanilla Ice Cream
Maple-Poached Apples With Cinnamon- Glazed Pecans And Cider Granite
Zucchini Gratin With Parsley and Thyme
Zucchini Pickles With Chilies and Garlic
Zucchini Boats With Lamb And Yogurt Fillings
Union Square Cafe's Tuna Club Sandwich
description: This update on a workaday sandwich takes time and work, it’s true. But the result, Julia Reed says, is the best old-fashioned tuna salad sandwich you’ve ever had in your life. You’ll need two pounds of yellowfin tuna, which you’ll poach with aromatics, cool and then mix with a few chopped peppers, fennel seed, onion and herbs. If you plan ahead, you can make the tuna salad without the herbs, refrigerate it overnight, and add them in before assembling your sandwiches. Layer it on toasted bread with a lemon-pepper aioli, slab bacon and arugula. This is picnic food for the gods.

title: My Mother's Tuna Salad
description: This is Julia Reed’s favorite tuna salad, the one she subsisted on for years as a child, eaten with a fork straight out of a container in her mother’s refrigerator. It’s an unfussy thing that is exactly suited to be layered between two pieces of white bread — toasted, if you must — and then eaten at the kitchen table, or, after summer ends, at the lunchroom table. The ingredients are simple and easily acquired, and be sure to use real mayonnaise.

title: Yukon Gold Potato Knishes With Osetra Caviar
recipe_yield: 8 to 12 appetizer-size servings (36 pieces in all)

title: Cold Cauliflower Soup With Aioli and Clams
Duck Gumbo
ingredients: large red bell pepper, in 1/4-inch dice
large green bell pepper, in medium dice

title: Creole Gumbo
description: Leah Chase, the chef and owner of Dooky Chase in New Orleans, gave an interview to Matt Lee and Ted Lee of The Times back in 2000. It was about her gumbo, which is brackish and silky and delicious, and for which she offered a recipe. Ms. Chase told them about giving a dinner in 1942 for a group of Tuskegee Airmen who refused to eat the gumbo she and a friend had prepared for them because they thought the file powder she put in the pot was a voodoo potion intended to ensnare the men. “One of the men was telling the others, 'Don't eat the gumbo! If you eat that gumbo, you'll never leave New Orleans.' '' Perhaps! (Sam Sifton)

title: Pepper Pot With Shellfish And Squash
Frisee Salad With Shrimp, Fennel and Mandarin Oranges
Hashed Brussels Sprouts With Poppy Seeds
Sauteed Sea Scallops With Shallots and Tomatoes
Mexican White Shrimp In Champagne Sauce
Surinam Shrimp With Tomatoes And Blood Oranges
Rock Shrimp With Basil Oil and Warm Bean Salad
All-in-One Chocolate Cake
description: This is the perfect chocolate cake: beautiful, melting, intense but not heavy. The batter comes together quickly in a food processor, and the cake bakes at 350 degrees for a while, giving the baker time to assemble the frosting, which is given a luscious sheen by a bit of corn syrup. Use the best chocolate you can find for the frosting, and gild it however you like: with a few flowers, some birthday candles or nothing at all.

title: Chocolate and Salty Peanut Cookies
description: These cookies offer a terrific blend of salty and sweet, with the crunch of the peanuts lending a bit of texture to a chewy treat. They are also very easy to make and require only about an hour. But do watch the timer -- if they are overcooked, they will lose their chewiness.

title: Teddie's Apple Cake
description: In a modern world of Cinnamon Hot Pockets and Pecan Pie Pringles, apple-picking is one of the few agricultural rituals we can all still get our hands into. This cake — a classic from 1973 — is a godsend to anyone who has overloaded at the pick-your-own orchard or overbought at the farmers’ market. Like many simple cakes, this one uses neutral oil that lets the fruit flavor come through, rather than show-offy butter.

title: Spiced Soufflé Crepe With Sautéed Apples
description: Tart apples are particularly abundant this time of year. Portnoy used Granny Smith apples, but you can try this recipe with Empire, Macoun, Honeycrisp, Winesap or Pippin.

title: Pasta With Anchovies And Bread Crumbs
Chicken Breasts in Crusty Potato Batter
Linguine With Arugula, Tomatoes and Potatoes
Carter House Salmon With Morel-and-Asparagus Ragout
Wild Bass With Bing Cherry Chutney and Hazelnut Hollandaise
Omelet With Pork and Wild Greens
Phyllo With Fresh Cheese and Mint
Kittichai's Rice Crackers With Chicken-And-Shrimp Dipping Sauce
Broccoli Rabe Salad With Chili-Soy Vinaigrette
Pasta With Spicy Broccoli Rabe and Pine Nuts
Creamy Broccoli Soup With Broccoli Rabe
Broccoli Parmesan Gratin
recipe_yield: Four main-course or six side-dish servings

title: Broccoli Rabe With Hot Italian Sausage
Patrick Clark's Crab With Arugula and Macadamias
Jeremiah Tower's Duck With Endive Salad
Buttered Cabbage And Parma Ham Topping
Charcoal-Grilled Tuna Steaks With Mango Chutney
Bright Rice
description: This colorful dish is great on a dreary day, or any other time for that matter. It doesn’t take long and can be a side for any chicken or fish dish -- or, as Nigella Lawson originally suggested, as a perfect accompaniment to dal, a red lentil stew spiced with turmeric, chili and ginger, and colored with sweet potatoes and tomatoes.

title: Cucumber And Cilantro Raita
description: When the season permits, you can change this dish into a jewel-studded pomegranate raita: simply substitute pomegranate seeds for the cucumber and cilantro. In either case remember to add a good pinch of salt to the yogurt.

title: Focaccia With Vegetables And Parmigiano Reggiano
Bun Ga Nuong (Chicken and Vermicelli)
description: Grilled chicken is tossed with rice vermicelli in a chili vinaigrette flavored with fresh lime juice.

title: Agnello Cacio E Uova (Neapolitan Fricassee Of Spring Lamb)
Taillevent's Chocolate Cake With Pistachio Sauce
Chocolate Souffle With Melted Chocolate Center
The Bobby Flay Burger
description: Back in 2003, before he was a fast-food impresario, Bobby Flay gave this recipe for a Cubano-style burger to Jonathan Reynolds of The Times. “The best burgers are made on an iron surface and cooked medium, so they're not too soft and you can get a crust,” he said at the time. “If you press your burger bun like a Cubano, you get crisp on the outside, soft on the inside.” He adorned the patty with two slices of Swiss, smoked ham and pickles, then slipped the package into the bun and pressed it hard on the grill. “We are not ready for micro greens on our national dish,” he said. The result continues to amaze.

title: Mario Batali's Spaghetti on a Stick
Pasta With Lemon, Herbs and Ricotta Salata
description: Here's a light, brothy pasta with chicken stock, lemon zest, mint and ricotta salata that Amanda Hesser brought to The Times in 2001. It's easy yet elegant; perfect for a impromptu weeknight dinner party. If you can get your hands on a Meyer lemon, do so and use that, but the recipe works just as well with a standard lemon from the corner deli.

title: A Versatile Green Broccoli-Rabe Pasta Sauce
Broccoli Rabe and Cannellini Bean Salad
recipe_yield: Six servings as a side dish

title: Broccoli Rabe With Italian Sausage
recipe_yield: Four servings as a main course

title: Chicken With Tomato Sauce And Polenta Triangles
Beet Soup With Greens, Apple Salad and Cilantro-Walnut Pesto
Tuna With Black-Eyed Pea and Artichoke Salad
Shrimp With Coriander And Mustard Seeds and Sweet-Potato Hash
recipe_yield: Four first-course or two main-course servings

title: Slow-Cooked Leg Of Lamb With Fresh Mint Sauce
Sweet And Salty Popcorn With Orange-Blossom Honey
Cauliflower With Almonds And Brown Butter
Cauliflower, Beets And Watercress With Orange Ginger Dressing
Sauteed Cauliflower With Bread Crumbs, Parsley, Capers And Olives
Cauliflower Soup With Cremini Mushrooms And Walnut Oil
Rib Steaks With Parsley And Crouton Salad
Fennel Baked With Tomatoes and Parmesan
Rosemary-Grilled Scallops
recipe_yield: 6 appetizer servings or 4 main course servings

title: Plantation Shrimp On Sugar Cane Skewers
recipe_yield: 6 to 8 appetizer servings, 4 light main course servings

title: Fish Mousse Grilled On Lemon Grass (Sate Lilit)
recipe_yield: 6 to 8 appetizer servings, 2 to 3 main course servings

title: Pan-Seared Halibut Steaks With Snap-Pea Sauce and Garnish
Snap Peas and Shiitake Mushrooms In Scallion Crepes With Lemon Zest
Eight-Treasure Rice Pudding
description: Here is a sticky, sweet end to a Chinese repast, and most of it can be prepared a few days ahead of time. Red-bean paste and candied fruits can be found in most Asian markets, or try the Asian-food aisle at a supermarket for lichees.

title: Standard Mayonnaise
description: Hellmann's is a fine product. But homemade mayonnaise is something entirely different. It is perfectly delicious spread on sandwiches, but it can also become the foundation of a more complex dipping sauce or dressing. Make sure you use a mildly flavored oil so the richness of the egg, as fresh as you can find, can shine.

title: Potato And Smoked Mackerel Salad With Creamy Mayonnaise
Cabbage Salad With Toasted Coriander And Cumin Mayonnaise
Chicken And Avocado Salad With Lime Mayonnaise
Lobster Fricassee With Artichoke Coulis And Tarragon
Wild Rice and Orzo With Tarragon
Grilled Asparagus With Lemon Dressing
description: Although steamed asparagus has an unmatched purity of taste, I love the earthy, charred flavor added by the grill, a flavor that can also be achieved with stove-top pan grilling, which combines high heat and a dry, heavy skillet.

title: Calf's Liver With Capers and Black Butter
Sauteed Potatoes With Sweet Red Peppers
Mashed Yellow Turnips With Crispy Shallots
Brioche Tarts With Blue Cheese, Walnuts And Quince
Chilled Rhubarb Soup and  Vanilla Ice Cream
Crisp Smelts With Confit of Turnips in a Vinegar and Tomato Fondue
Black Bass in Watercress Broth, Ginger and Fava Beans
Duck Legs Braised With Red Wine and Lime
Spicy Pork Belly With Green Olives and Lemon
Polenta With Zucchini, Peppers and Cheese
Herbed Meat Loaf With Mushroom Sauce
Creamed Lump Crab Meat With Country Ham
Leg Of Lamb, North Indian Style
description: Lamb has a lot of flavor, and stands up to strong spices brilliantly. Here is a recipe for boneless leg of lamb that you could grill, broil or roast in a hot oven. Regardless, the result is a crisp, crunchy and highly seasoned exterior with a tender, sweet interior. Even better, because the boned leg is invariably irregular in thickness, the meat will be cooked to different stages of doneness. If, for example, you cook it so that the thickest part of the meat reaches 125 degrees (rare), the thinner parts will vary from medium rare to nearly well done at the edges. Because lamb also tastes great at all stages of doneness, this will make for a genuine crowd-pleaser.

title: Macerated Sour Cherries And Mascarpone Cream
Watermelon Soup With Red Summer Berries and Lime
Nectarines and Berries With Flavored Whipped Cream
description: Macerated desserts are simply fruit steeped in a flavored sugar syrup, wine, liquor, vinegar or citrus juice, usually for a couple of hours or overnight. During the process, the fruit becomes slightly softer, its flavor infused with spices, juices or wine. Fruit can be nicely complemented not only by a simple sugar syrup, but also by orange or lemon juice, wine, liqueurs and vinegar.

title: Shad Roe With Black Butter Caper Sauce
Mako Shark With Green Peppercorn Sauce
Sauteed Shrimp In Ancho Chili Sauce
Turkey Burgers Stuffed With Salsa and Mozzarella
Berry Terrine In Muscat De Beaumes-De-Venise Jelly
Choucroute Loaf
description: This recipe for choucroute loaf, vaguely Alsatian in its addition of smoked ham, apples, mustard and caraway to the usual mixture of ground chuck, veal and pork, makes astonishing meatloaf and terrific Sunday lunch sandwiches afterward. Paired with sauerkraut, the dish winks at real choucroute and in some ways is even more delicious. For finicky kids, provide a side dish of mashed potatoes.

title: Bill Blass’s Meatloaf
description: This homespun, bacon-wrapped version of the American classic is attributed to Bill Blass, the world-famous clothing designer of the 60s, 70s and 80s, who is perhaps best known for dressing First Lady Nancy Reagan and the upper echelons of New York society. While he became hugely successful – he reportedly sold his business for $50 million in 1999 – his culinary tastes remained firmly Midwestern. From his

title: Anne Rosenzweig's Old-Fashioned Meat-And-Rice Loaf With Spiced Carrots
Lutece's Bay Scallops With Tomato and Chives
The Mark's Bay Scallops With Scallions And Sesame Seeds
Green Lentils With Roasted Beets and Preserved Lemon
Rack of Lamb With Rosemary and Balsamic Vinegar
Fresh Spaghetti With Tomatoes and Basil
Pastry Cream
ingredients: plump, moist vanilla bean, split lengthwise, pulp scraped out

title: Broccoli Rabe With Raisins and Garlic
Pot au Feu
ingredients: Mustard, horseradish, cornichons and sea salt

title: Parsley Potatoes
recipe_yield: 6 to 8 servings with pot au feu

title: Fragrant Beef Cooked In Mint And Spinach Leaves
Tomato Salad With Arugula Pesto And Beans
Beef Stew with Sweet and Hot Paprika
Kentucky Derby Mint Juleps
description: This is a real julep, the now classic julep first served to Derby guests in 1875 by Col. Meriwether Lewis Clark Jr., the founder of Churchill Downs. Now, as then, it is made with just four ingredients: finely crushed ice, a little sugar water, fresh spearmint and fine, aged, 90-proof straight Kentucky bourbon.

title: Sauteed Soft-Shell Crabs With Shrimp Amandine
‘Totally Local’ Gratin
description: All the ingredients listed in this recipe are local to New England. If you don't live there, do your best to substitute them with your own local ingredients. Or grow and make them yourself. (Just kidding.)

title: Cranberry Beans With Tomatoes and Herbs
Scallop-and-Halibut Ceviche Salad
description: This recipe came to The Times from Fanny Singer, the daughter of Alice Waters, the chef and food activist. It’s inspired by Ms. Singer’s favorite street food. Ceviche is almost always so astringent that the fish loses identity, but the freshness of the ingredients and softness of the lime marinade here are neither confrontational nor eye-squinching. It’s simple stuff: avocado, grapefruit, prickly chile, cilantro, lime and an absolutely fresh sea creature. Making the dish takes a bit of work, but it’s the perfect recipe for when you don’t want to turn on the stove.

title: Fresh Ham Roasted With Rye Bread and Dried Fruit Stuffing
Pork Loin With Mustard Seed Crust
Pork Chops Baked With Apples And Onions
Clam And Fregola Soup
recipe_yield: 4 servings as a first course, 2 as a main course

title: Country Ragout With Fregola
recipe_yield: 4 servings as a first course, 2 as a main course

title: Stuffed Breast of Veal
ingredients: Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste

title: Parsley Salad With Country Ham, Tomatoes and Asiago
Smoked Sturgeon Salad With Leeks, Haricots Verts And Frisee
Wedge Salad With Buttermilk-Blue Cheese Dressing
Cumin Chicken With Black Bean Sauce
Chicken and Chickpea Tagine
description: Like many dishes that rely on combinations of spices, a tagine, which is a slowly braised stew, may look more intimidating to cook than it is. Even with shortcuts, the results are exotic in flavor and appearance. My version of this tagine may not compare to those that begin with toasting and grinding spices and peeling grapes, but it is easily executed and, I think, divine.

title: Roasted Asparagus With Crunchy Parmesan Topping
Blackberry Jam Cake With Caramel Icing
Pizzocheri With Cabbage, Potatoes and Sage
Seared Sea Scallops With Lime-Ginger Sauce and Caramelized Endive
Fresh Morel, Asparagus and Sweet-Pea Risotto
Rack of Lamb With Fava Beans And Roasted Garlic Custard
ingredients: racks of lamb, trimmed and Frenched (ask your butcher to do this), trimmings reserved
large onion, peeled and coarsely chopped
kosher salt, plus more to taste

title: Rice and Zucchini
description: The recipe for rice with zucchini in the 60-Minute Gourmet column in The Living Section last Wednesday omitted a step. Here is a corrected version.

title: Horse’s Neck
description: This recipe for the classic bourbon (sometimes brandy) and ginger ale highball came to us from the Campbell Apartment, a cocktail lounge in Grand Central Station.

title: I Trulli's White Anchovy And Orange Salad
Spartina's Roasted Cod With Nicoise Vinaigrette
Bowl of the Wife of Kit Carson
Veal Patties Stuffed With Ham and Cheese
Figs and Blueberries In Citrus Broth
Plum Almond Tart With Plum Compote
Sautéed Red Snapper With Rhubarb Sauce
Braised White Asparagus With Blood-Orange Sauce
Turnip Pancakes Topped With Cod And Smoked Salmon
ingredients: medium turnips, peeled and cut into 1-inch cubes
nickel-size slices of fresh ginger, peeled and lightly smashed

title: Chicken Stuffed With Mashed Turnips
ingredients: medium turnips, peeled and cut in 1/2-inch cubes
medium baking potato, peeled and cut in 1/2-inch cubes

title: Gratin Of Turnips With Chicory And White Beans
Boiled Dinner With Turnips And Ham Hocks
Pot Roast with Soy or Lima Beans

ingredients: leg of lamb, boned and butterflied (opened with meat scored slightly to flatten it)
title: Herbed and Butterflied Leg of Lamb
Oven-Roasted Oysters
description: In New York, as in most North American cities these days, oysters are relatively plentiful, whether they're harvested locally or flown in from afar. Open space for lighting bonfires, however, is in decidedly short supply, so we set about adapting the oyster roast's winning combination of extreme informality and indulgence to a city setting.

title: Grilled Pork Chops With Vidalia Onions
ingredients: center-cut pork chops, about 1 1/4 inches thick

title: Stir-Fried Chicken With Ketchup
description: I learned about the genesis of this dish from Suvir Saran, an Indian chef in New York. This dish is Manchurian in origin and is based on an ingredient that is in almost every refrigerator. It's stir-fried chicken with ketchup, and before you turn your nose up, think how good ketchup can taste. In the version he cooked for me, Mr. Saran tossed cauliflower in a slurry of cornstarch and egg, then deep-fried it. The crust was exquisite, and the cauliflower perfectly cooked. But it was what happened next that really got my attention: He finished the cauliflower in a sauce, made in about three minutes, containing nothing more than ketchup, garlic and cayenne pepper.

title: Steamed Spring Vegetables in Warm Leek Vinaigrette
Lamb and Roasted Potato and Artichoke Salads
Warm Scallop Puddings With Spinach and Cold Tomato-Basil Juice
Lamb Chops With Sweet Pea and Spinach Sauce

ingredients: chilled vegetable shortening, cut into bits
title: Spy Wednesday Biscuits
description: Brother Rick Curry shared this Holy Week recipe with The New York Times in 1994. These feathery sconelike biscuits are named for Spy Wednesday -- the day the soldiers spied on Christ.

title: Potato and Chickpea Soup With Yogurt
Veal and Pork Burgers With Paprika Sauce
Rice and Minted Peas
ingredients: fresh mint to yield 1 tablespoon chopped

title: Orange, Chili And Rosemary Steaming Liquid
Trout with Sticky Rice, Zucchini And Pine Nuts
ingredients: Orange, chili and rosemary steaming liquid

title: Curried Lentil And Grilled Chicken Casserole
Degustation of Wild Mushrooms With Soft Polenta
Cumin Orange Tomato Sauce
description: This sauce is an excellent compliment to traditional cod cakes, as well as those scented with ginger.

title: Cucumber Mint Sauce
description: This sauce makes a tart contrast to the soy and chili sauce that is often served with Thai shrimp cakes. It also makes a wonderful foil for spicy salmon cakes.

title: Slow Roasted Duck With Orange-Sherry Sauce
description: The New Orleans raconteur Pableaux Johnson scored this recipe from Greg Sonnier of Gabrielle restaurant in the Mid-City neighborhood back in 2004, calling it a reflection "of the dual nature of New Orleans cookery." Inspired by the haute cuisine of K-Paul's Louisiana Kitchen, where Mr. Sonnier got his start, it also takes more than a bow toward the city's legendary street food tradition of gravy-soaked po' boys laden with French fries. At the restaurant, Mr. Sonnier served the dish over shoestring potatoes. Home cooks can substitute mock frites or hash browns. Either way, the interplay between the moist meat, luscious sauce and crisp potatoes is nonpareil. (Sam Sifton)

title: Roasted And Braised Duck With Sauerkraut
Leftovers Deluxe The Tuscan Way Ribollita
Jane Grigson's Peas In the Pod
Pasta With Mushrooms, Cauliflower and Peas
Barley Baked With Olives And Sun-Dried Tomatoes
ingredients: hot chicken, beef or vegetable stock

title: Brown Rice With Fennel And Asparagus
ingredients: Salt and freshly ground black pepper

title: Kasha With Broccoli Rabe And Fontina
Pimms Gelée With Raspberries And Fromage Blanc
Creamy Gruyere Potatoes
ingredients: medium baking potatoes, peeled and cut across into 1/8-inch slices
unsalted butter, cut into small pieces

title: Mushrooms Poached With Coriander And Lemon
Warm Alaskan King Crab With Mushroom Salad
Grilled Veal Chops With Grilled Potatoes
Roasted Bay Scallops With Brown Butter And Shallots
Pizza With Tomatoes, Corn, Sausage and Peppers
Pork Loin Marinated in Paprika and Herbs
Max Treitler's Fesenjan (Chicken With Pomegranate and Walnut Sauce)
Culotte Steaks With Onion Glaze And Horseradish Bread Crumbs
Zabar's Black-and-Whites
description: The black-and-white cookie, that frumpy and oversize mainstay of New York City bakeries and delis, has not endured by dint of its taste. Unlike other edible icons, like New York cheesecake or bagels, there is no such thing as a delicious black-and-white cookie. They are either edible or inedible. Fresh-baked and home-baked are the best.

title: Turkey Chili
description: You might not think of chili as an easy weeknight dish, but this turkey version from Pierre Franey will change your mind. It's fabulous, it's healthy and it can be ready in about a half hour. A combination of dark and white meat really adds depth and richness of flavor, so try to find a mix, but all white meat (or a mixture of ground beef and turkey) will yield a stellar batch too.

title: Montauk Bluefin-Tuna Tartar With Fresh Herbs
description: This recipe is totally inspired by the freshness of the ingredients. The tuna has to be of the best sashimi quality, preferably from a belly cut where there is more fat. As for the herbs, I harvest them from our farm just before I start the preparation, and then I mince them with a very sharp knife so as not to bruise them.''

title: Marjoram-Scented Black Bass, Grilled Over Wood Fire
description: Grilling has become my favorite way to cook fish, especially when it's still whole. This way the meat is protected by the skin and bones, which allows for gentle cooking, even over low heat. Here, I use relatively strong flavorings and seasongs which, in combination with the mild wood smoke, produces a delicious result.''

title: Slow-Roasted Heirloom Tomatoes With Fresh Thyme
description: Like any other tomato recipe, this dish lives or dies with the perfectly ripened tomato. Commercial growers breed for size, shape and hardiness of shipping, but you should put your emphasis on taste rather than appearance. I'm a willing taker for tomatoes that are not so stunning-looking because I know how good they taste.''

title: Spicy Corn Stew
description: Given a choice, I always prefer white corn -- the sweetest and most tender you can find. Although new hybrids make corn on the cob much hardier and longer-lasting than it used to be, I am still from the out-of-the-fields-and-into-the-pot school of corn cooking. If you don't grow your own, try to find a farmer's market that sells fresh corn picked that morning.''

title: Lemon-Verbena-Peach-and-Raspberry Soup
description: Since we started our farm, I've rediscovered many vegetables and herbs that are not quite so mainstream. Lemon verbena is one of them. I'd often heard about it but never quite understood its fascination until we began growing it.''

title: Jean Halberstam's Deep-Fried Peaches
description: Jean Halberstam, who was married to the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist David Halberstam until his death in 2007, is a well-known, accomplished cook. To make this dessert for a 2005 dinner party at their home on Nantucket, she plunged skinless peach halves into a batter, then sizzled them in a bath of boiling Crisco — yes, Crisco; “Nothing else makes them as crisp,” she said — until lightly browned, and rolled them in sugar. Her dinner guests could not believe how good these were.

title: Oven-Baked Porcini On a Bed of Potatoes
Pasta With Pesto, Potatoes and Broccoli
Little Fish Cakes in Banana Leaves
Sea Bass Baked in Coconut Milk
Paella With Chicken, Chorizo And Shrimp
Pork, Chickpea And Red Pepper Paella
Lamb With Vegetables and Yogurt Sauce in a Pita
Squid Pasta With Light Garlic Sauce
Asian Slaw
ingredients: medium-size cucumbers, peeled, seeded and cut in julienne
finely minced seeded fresh red chili, or to taste

title: Orange Sour Cream Cake With Blueberry Compote
Blood Orange, Date And Parmesan Salad With Almond Oil
Biscotti-Plum Pudding With Spiced Red-Wine Syrup

ingredients: woodchuck, dressed and cleaned of scent glands, boned and cut into strips or bite-size chunks (see note)
pitted Cerignola olives, very coarsely chopped
title: Woodchuck au Vin
recipe_yield: 3 to 6 servings, depending on size of woodchuck
description: The gardener who created this dish notes that the herbs and vegetables in this recipe are available fresh from the garden because they have not been eaten by the dish's main ingredient.

title: Striped Bass Poached In Spicy Soy Sauce
description: Poaching fish in a mixture of soy sauce and water is a simple, fast method that adds gorgeous flavor to fillets, which emerge moist and succulent. It is also flexible and forgiving, with a cooking liquid that can accommodate a host of seasonings. Here those seasonings are sugar (to cut the saltiness of the soy sauce), scallions and an optional fresh or dried chile pepper (either minced or put in whole), but you could experiment with ginger, garlic, lime juice or other flavors. Combine all the ingredients, except the bass, in a skillet. Bring to a boil, add the fish flesh-side-down, and adjust the heat so that the mixture does not bubble too aggressively. The fish cooks in 8 to 10 minutes, until its flesh is mahogany-colored and doesn’t resist when you slice in with a thin-bladed knife. Serve on top of rice, garnished with the cooking liquid and the scallions, which are now limp and tender. Other fish, like cod, halibut, monkfish and salmon, also work, but keep an eye on it as it poaches — you will likely need to adjust the cooking time slightly.

title: Pecan Coffee Cake With Warm Caramel Sauce
description: This nutty sour cream coffee cake is rich enough to stand alone, but the bourbon caramel sauce elevates it to “special occasion dessert” status.

title: Chocolate Silk Pie
description: Light yet rich, this magical dessert is like the grown-up version of the chocolate pudding pie of your youth. It requires a bit more work, but nothing terribly taxing. Just whip melted chocolate, butter and eggs into a mousse, and then pour it all into a chocolate cookie crust. Chill and enjoy. It's the perfect make-ahead dessert for a crowd.

title: Roast Chicken, And Salad The Day After
Fricassee Of Cod With Red-Pepper Compote
Roast Pork With Milk
description: A bistro basic that the critic Bryan Miller brought to The Times in 1988 with the help of Pierre Franey, this luscious roast of pork comes from the kitchen of Adrienne Biasin, who for years ran a homespun and legendary restaurant in Paris, Chez la Vieille. The meat is first browned over the stovetop to sear in the moisture, then braised slowly in onions and milk. The pan juices are set aside to form the base of a gravy, and the roast is finished in the oven. It takes some time, but is beyond easy to make, and pairs well with a glass of Beaujolais and dreams of travel. (Sam Sifton)

title: Le Lapin A La Moutarde D'irene (Rabbit Stew With Mustard)
Spring Onion Pudding With Horseradish Steamed Trout
Braised Veal With Cardamom-Spinach Puree

title: Almond Cake With Rhubarb Compote and Strawberries
ingredients: rhubarb, trimmed, cut into 1 1/4-inch lengths and then cut lengthwise into thin slices

title: Asparagus With Red And Yellow Pepper Coulis
Roast Leg of Lamb With Garlic Rosemary Sauce
Fava Beans With Mint, Potatoes and Artichokes
Soft-Shell Crabs With Corn and Onion Sauce
Red Pepper Dip With Walnuts And Pomegranate
description: This dish, called muhammara, is a beautiful coarse purée of roasted red peppers, chilies, walnuts, garlic and pomegranate molasses.

title: Moroccan Rice Pudding
description: For me, a dinner party is a chance to try all those recipes that serve as bedside reading. I dug around my cookbook collection and decided on a tabbouleh scented with cinnamon and a rice pudding, roz bil hleeb, made with almond milk and orange flower water.

title: Duck Breasts Poached In Red Wine And Port
Cold Poached Salmon With Green Coriander Mayonnaise
Broiled Or Grilled Chicken With Coconut And Lime
Sea Bass in Black Bean Sauce
description: Do not be alarmed by this list of ingredients. This dish is much simpler to prepare than it may seem.

title: Mark Bittman’s Shrimp In Green Sauce
description: Green sauce means different things to different cooks, but I like the Iberian interpretation best. It draws its color from parsley and its impact from chilies, scallions, and, mostly, garlic. I find it difficult to use too much garlic here, and have never really reached the outer limit; my recipe calls for six cloves, but twice that amount is not unreasonable.

title: Lemongrass Nage
recipe_yield: Eight first courses or four main courses

title: Chilled Cucumber Soup With Warm Salmon
Pithiviers Of Rhubarb With Strawberry Sauce
Macerated Peaches With Chamomile Ice Milk and Brioche
Red Rice With Cockles And Chorizo
Five-Spice Jasmine Rice With Portobello Mushrooms
ingredients: portobello mushroom caps, cut in 3/4-inch dice

title: Brown Basmati With Coconut, Almonds And Currants
Baked Hominy Casserole With Chilies and Chicken
New England Spider Cake
description: This is a creamy, corny skillet preparation from New England, which has delighted roomfuls of people every time I've served it. So-called because of the veins created by the cream in its vortex, which separates the crumb during baking, this substantial one-skillet meal will get your kids to school happier than they've ever been, and you happy only if they've left some behind. As my recipe tester, Alice Thompson, responded: ''Spider cake rules! How has this escaped the culinary radar so far? Where has it been all my life?''

title: Chicken With Almonds and Green Olives
Red Pepper Vichyssoise
ingredients: red bell peppers, seeded and cut into quarters
large baking potato, peeled and diced

title: Frascatelli With Parsley, Garlic And Pecorino
Soft White Dinner Rolls
description: Getting supper on the table quickly makes you feel efficient. Baking a batch of soft dinner rolls makes you feel cozily competent. This may be an unfashionable virtue, but it is also a deeply satisfying one.

title: Chocolate and Pistachio Whirligig Buns
description: This recipe was brought to The Times in 2003 by Nigella Lawson, the British cookbook author and culinary celebrity, as part of an article encouraging readers to bake with yeast – an act all too often unnecessarily fraught with anxiety. The payoff for tackling one's fear, she argued, is big. Enter these pillowy, butter-rich buns dotted with semisweet chocolate and pistachios. They are not difficult – if you can follow directions, you can make them (really!) – and they are insanely delicious. You can also fill them with marmalade, or with honey and chopped walnuts.

title: Steak au Poivre
ingredients: mixed peppercorns (long pepper, Pondicherry, cubeb and Tasmanian black pepper)
steaks, 1 1/2 inches thick, 10 to 12 ounces each
green peppercorns in brine, rinsed and drained

Hot Zucchini and Pepper Basil Sauce With Penne
Mixed Greens and Tomatoes With Raspberry Vinaigrette
Cod Baked With Prosciutto
description: Cod with prosciutto and

title: French Lentils With Garlic and Thyme
description: This is a classic French way to cook lentils, and it’s very easy. Aromatics pulsed in a food processor are sautéed and then simmered with French lentils, also known as Le Puy lentils, for 20 to 25 minutes. It is an easy side dish (shown here with

title: Fast Pot-Stickers
description: What can make pot-stickers a minimalist dish? One approach is called takeout and is already quite common. The alternative is using the wrappers now sold in just about every supermarket. Start with those, and a filling of ground pork (beef, chicken, turkey and lamb also work), cabbage, scallions, ginger and garlic. For a vegetarian pot-sticker, cabbage can dominate, complemented by chopped shiitakes, minced tofu, minced celery and carrots, chives or a combination. Wrap, seal and cook.

title: Pan-Roasted Pork Ribs With Caramelized Onions
Red-Pepper Sauce With Hazelnut Butter
ingredients: red bell peppers, seeded and coarsely chopped
Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste

title: Veloute of Parsley With Truffle Oil
Salmon With Pea Sauce And Herb Salad
Mushroom and Barley Ragout
description: This healthy and simple side dish can be prepared ahead of time. It's a perfect standby to re-heat throughout the week and pair with your choice of meat or other protein.

title: Ceylon Curry of Oysters
description: This recipe appeared in The Times in an article by Charlotte Hughes. In Hughes's original recipe, she called for three bay leaves; I used only one. And since chilies are now commonly available, I used a serrano rather than the sweet green pepper that Hughes suggested.

title: Steamed Wild Striped Bass With Coconut Rice and Apple-Banana Chutney
Red Potato Salad With Mustard And Bacon
Lattice-Top Strawberry Pie
description: Here is a classic American strawberry pie from Molly O’Neill, who developed the recipe after interviewing dozens of American soldiers for an article about taste and memory. The idea, she wrote, was to “try to approximate the fantasies of the returning soldiers and pretend, right along with them, that what has passed will not affect what lies ahead.”

The key to cooking chicken wings is to get the meat tender and the skin crisp. Eating them poses an altogether different challenge. It requires a certain comfort level with stickiness — plus a heap of wet wipes and some dexterity with your teeth.
title: Fried Sambal Wings With Cucumber Cream
Slow-Roasted Pork for Tacos
description: To make tacos for a crowd, you can’t do better than to begin with slow-roasted pork, scented with cumin and coriander, garlic and red pepper. Use shoulder or butt meat and you won’t go wrong, as the high fat content makes the meat self-basting. Slow, indirect grilling is ideal, but you don’t lose much by cooking the pork in the oven, using moderate heat. Shred and serve on warm tortillas.

title: Grilled Carne Asada for Tacos
description: Carne asada means “grilled meat,” which in turn can mean a lot. But skirt steak is what you most often see made into carne asada (and in some supermarkets, skirt steak is called carne asada). Because of its high fat content, it’s perfect for tacos. Rub it with a few spices, grill it for a few minutes and pile it into tortillas with a couple of other ingredients. Dinner in a flash.

title: Shredded Chicken for Tacos
description: Just about anything can be called a taco, which essentially means “sandwich.” You take a tortilla and you put some stuff in it and you eat it; that’s a taco. (If you roll the tortilla, it’s a burrito, which appears to have been created in the American Southwest; if you layer food on top of it, it’s an enchilada; if you crisp it up and use it as a kind of plate, it’s a tostada; if you cut it into pieces and bake or fry it, it’s a chip; and so on.) But taco aficionados have a particular taste, a particular feel in mind. It’s about the ingredients, as high quality and as fresh as possible. Chicken thighs —  from a good chicken rather than a super-mass-produced one — are a good option, and can be quickly simmered in a flavorful braising liquid that will turn them super-tender and leave them quite moist. The seasonings can be varied as you like. I see the spice mixtures in this recipe as suggestions rather than ironclad rules to follow.

title: Veal Chops With Spinach and Pancetta
Pasta Casserole With Goat Cheese and Salsa
Brined Turkey
description: This recipe, from the barbecue expert Steven Raichlen, was originally published alongside a pair of recipes for smoking the Thanksgiving turkey: one that has you

title: Turkey Smoked Outdoors
description: There are countless advantages to smoke-roasting (also known barbecuing) your turkey, as in this recipe from the barbecue expert Steven Raichlen. Smoking produces a bird of incomparable succulence, especially when combined with another traditional American barbecue technique, brining. There is the rich, evocative flavor of wood smoke, and the burnished mahogany sheen it gives the bird. Then there's the simplicity of the method: once you put the bird in the smoker or on the grill, you pretty much leave it there until it is done, while the kitchen and oven are freed up for side dishes and desserts. Last but certainly not least, you get an excuse to spend a fall afternoon outdoors, maybe with beer in hand.

title: Madeira Gravy
description: Maderia, a fortified wine, brings wonderful flavor to this Thanksgiving pan gravy, quickly whisked together after the bird emerges from the oven. As with any gravy, the flavor of the stock is essential here, so it's absolutely worth the time to make your own.

title: Sautéed Cauliflower with Apples and Sherry
Sautéed Broccoli With Toasted Garlic, Orange and Sesame
Fish with Shiitakes
description: This dish is the kind that, with a little experience, many good cooks could assemble from scratch, without consulting a recipe. The aromatic triumvirate of garlic, ginger and scallions is matched with soy sauce, rice vinegar and fish sauce. Shiitake mushrooms give substance and flavor, cornstarch thickens and sesame oil adds a whiff of toasty richness.

title: Sauteed Medallions of Pork With Prunes
Roast Chicken With Olive-Coriander Juice And Chickpea Fries
Lamb Salad With Cucumber and Mint
recipe_yield: Four first-course or two main-course servings

title: Chicken With Pancetta And Balsamic Vinegar
Pierre Franey’s Coleslaw
description: Pierre Franey, that consummate reinterpreter of American cooking, provided this recipe for a Dijon-and-honey spiked coleslaw to The Times in a “60 Minute Gourmet” column in 1990. (It takes much less time to prepare than that.) The result pairs beautifully with any fried seafood and many grilled meats, particularly those scented with soy or curry. It will improve in flavor over the course of a few hours, so it is a good recipe to make in the heat of a weekend day, ahead of an evening barbecue.

title: Curried Summer Squash Soup With Yuba and Cilantro
Casserole of Cornish Hens And New Potatoes
Tagliarini With Mushrooms, Garlic and Sage
Grilled Tuna Burger With Ginger Mayonnaise
Boiled Leg of Lamb With Lemon-Caper Sauce
Turnip Puree With Orange and Nutmeg
Aztec Hot Chocolate Pudding
description: It looks alarming when you make it -- it's hard to believe that sprinkling sugar and cocoa on top of a cake batter and then pouring hot water over it will end up edible, but it does, it truly does. This is a luscious, homey dessert, one of those self-saucing puddings that turn themselves as they bake into a layer of gooey sauce topped with tender cake.

title: Pasta With Spinach And Blue Cheese
The Boston Ritz-Carlton's Creamed Finnan Haddie
Pea Soup With Pancetta And Croutons
Sauteed Brussels Sprouts With Pancetta And Chestnuts
Baked Rice With Brussels Sprouts And Chicken
Lamb Chops With Brussels Sprouts, Red Peppers and Ginger
Ricotta Kisses
description: These baci di ricotta -- perfect kisses, hot, soft and melting -- are a surprisingly easy dessert. It's just a question of mixing the ingredients in a bowl (by hand) and then frying rounded teaspoonfuls of the batter in just under an inch of oil until you have some light, small, vaguely ball-shaped fritters that need no more than a powdery dusting with confectioners' sugar. Put a dish mounded with them on the table with coffee and watch them go.

title: Roasted Capon With Black Truffles and Chanterelle Stuffing
Paillard of Portobello Mushroom Glazed With Balsamic Vinegar
Slow-Cooked Beef Cheeks With Spring Vegetables and Rosemary
Spiced Pasta, Avocado and Onion-Feta Salad
Basil, Snap Pea And Rice Salad With Creamy Yogurt Dressing
Zucchini-Herb, Grilled Eggplant And Tomato Salad
Caramelized Oranges With Chocolate Shortbread and Caramel Ice Cream
Creamy Lemon Pasta
description: This astonishingly delicious pasta dish is surprisingly easy to make. Just combine the zest of two lemons, heavy cream, salt and pepper in a saucepan, and let it come to a boil. Pour over freshly cooked egg noodles, add fresh lemon juice and toss. Cook for a couple minutes until the sauce has thickened slightly and cloaks the noodles in a rich, creamy, lemony brightness. It's luxurious weeknight cooking at its best.

title: Spaghetti With Fried Eggs
description: Here's a quick and delicious pasta dish to make when you have little time, and even less food in the house. All you need is a box of spaghetti, four eggs, olive oil and garlic (Parmesan is a delicious, but optional, addition).

title: Chocolate Hazelnut Cakes With Fennel Confit
Cassolette Of Morels, Fiddleheads And Asparagus
Roulade Of Rainbow Trout With Morel Mushroom Duxelles
recipe_yield: Four appetizer servings or two main-course servings

Smoked Chicken And Wild Rice Salad
Frito Misto Of Artichokes And Fennel
Shaved Artichoke Salad With Pine Nuts And Parmesan Cheese
Cold Potato Soup With Lobster Salad
Iced Tomato Puree With Cracked-Wheat Salad
Cold Herb Soup With Bread Salad and Chicken
Fresh Pea Soup With Shrimp, Basil and Mint
Frankie Harding's Chicken or Shrimp Curry
Chopped Summer Salad With Beets and Goat Cheese
Black Bass With Watercress And Tangerine Salad
Denver Chocolate Sheet Cake
description: Since the 1950s, when the Junior League first started publishing cookbooks to raise money for charity, it has sold hundred of millions of copies. The recipe came to The New York Times in 2003 from the Denver chapter: a chocolate sheet-cake recipe of tremendous moistness, easy to make.

title: Sauteed Turkey With Lemon and Capers
Brussels Sprouts, Roasted Red Peppers and Rice
Peach Sangria
description: This recipe came to The Times from David Mas Masumoto, who is an organic-peach-and-grape farmer and author. The drink is bright and fizzy and full of delicious summer. It’s a great accompaniment to brunch, or just an excellent way to end a hot day.

title: Spiced Grilled Lamb With Peach Chutney

description: Why doesn't maple syrup find its way to American cheese platters the way chestnut honey does to Italian ones? We think it works particularly well with subtle, creamy cheeses, a conviction that inspired our riff on a classic New York cheesecake.
title: New York Maple-Walnut Cheesecake
Malcolm and Kelley McDowell's Pink Rigatoni
Candied Ginger And Brandied Plum Sundaes
Chicken Breast With Eggplant, Shallots And Ginger
Leek, Mushroom and Goat Cheese Tart
Ragout of Chicken With Fresh Pasta
Chicken Soup With Flanken
description: Hana says: Take the flanken and chicken out of the soup when it's nearly done, and serve them separately. Leave the shinbone in so the meat is falling off the bone.

title: Potato Kugel
description: Make this ahead — the flavor really comes out after it has been reheated.

title: Apple Tart
recipe_yield: 24 servings plus one hour for chilling the dough.
description: Hana says: This tart is not kosher for Passover, so wait until after the holiday to make it. Gitta Friedenson, an old friend, passed along the recipe. Use a glass dish so you can check how brown the bottom gets. And don't serve it too hot, because it falls apart.

title: Curried Zucchini Soup With Apple Garnish

Flourless Orange Souffles With Grand Marnier Sauce
Home-Cured Sardine, Potato and Egg Salad
Hanger Steak with Olive Oil and Herbs
Mashed Potatoes and Sauteed Onions With Peas
Michelada
description: And just what is in a michelada? In Mexico City, it consists of fresh lime juice, a trinity of Tabasco, Worcestershire and soy sauces, a pinch of black pepper and maybe (or maybe not) a dash of Maggi, the seasoning usually used for soups and stews. This mix makes up two or three fingers' worth of a tall glass. That glass needs ice in it. It needs beer. And it needs drinking. At least, I certainly think it does. It might sound like a hangover recipe, but to me it tastes like malted manna.

title: Bacon-Wrapped Roast Pork Loin Stuffed With Dried Fruit
description: This impressive dish sounds far more complicated than it is. The oven does most of the work. Don't forget the sauce: the tang of the Dijon cream sauce is a welcome counter to the sweetness of the brandied fruit. Add a green salad (maybe some red potatoes?) and you have the perfect Sunday supper.

title: Curried Chicken Steamed in Banana Leaves
Coffee Walnut Layer Cake
description: This is a subtle cake: the coffee tempers the sweetness, and the buttery sweetness keeps it all mellow. Even if you don't make cakes, this one is a cinch. Don't be alarmed if the two sponge layers look thin when you unmold them. They are meant to be, because the cake gains a lot of height with its frosting. This cake is all about old-fashioned, homespun charm, so don't worry about how messy it looks: however the frosting goes on is fine. If you want to fully cover the sides of the cake, make a double batch of the frosting.

Wild Mushroom Broth With Buckwheat Noodles

Candied Squash and Ginger Relish
ingredients: minced lemon peel (cut from thin lemon slices)

title: Cold Poached Shrimp With Marjoram Pesto
Fish Poached In Buttermilk
description: Jean-Georges Vongerichten, the chef and an owner of Jo Jo, discovered this pairing one night when he tried a stuffing for poussin with the fish and buttermilk. It worked. The combination of fish and buttermilk, he said, was a natural. ''If you look at poached fish in classic cooking,'' he said, ''they're always being cooked in milk.'' The chef found that buttermilk kept the flesh of the fish white and added a desirable touch of acidity.

Here, you’ll whip it up in the food processor with fennel and cream cheese for a light spread. Serve it with baguette slices. It’s a quarter-hour of work for a savory, guest-friendly appetizer. (The New York Times)

Roasted Pepper and Green Bean Salad

description: Buckwheat noodles are often served cold in Japan and Korea, and are especially welcome during hot weather.

Kaffir Lime Meringue Cakes With Lime-Scented Papaya
Spring Salmon, Potato And Pesto Terrine

Potato Lasagna With Wild Mushrooms And Herb Sauce
Peppered Fillet Of Beef With Cranberries

Pork Tenderloin With Rhubarb, Pear, Rosemary and Honey
Crisp Rhubarb in a Sweet Broth
Jim Kelley's Roasted-Garlic-and-Pepper Soup
ingredients: garlic, roasted and squeezed from its husk
red bell peppers, roasted, peeled, seeded and coarsely chopped
small jalapeno peppers (to taste), prepared as above
onion, roasted, peeled and coarsely chopped
fresh goat cheese, cut into 6 slices

title: James Beard's Chicken With 40 Cloves of Garlic
description: This is a classic French fricassee, a Provençal dish popularized by Richard Olney, James Beard and other great cookbook writers of the postwar generation. An immense amount of garlic cooks slowly alongside the chicken, reducing the pungency of the cloves and replacing it with a thrumming sweetness and intensity. Eat the chicken in its sauce, then spread the softened garlic on bread and dip it in the remaining juices.

title: Pork and Watermelon Salad
description: The mixture of juicy watermelon and luscious pork fat make the effort of this project recipe well worth it. The recipe requires making a kind of quick pickle of the rind, which gives the dish added character.

title: Roast Leg of Lamb With Anchovies and Shallots
Potato Salad, Adapted By Joyce Stavely
Alici di Menaica in Olive Oil With Bread and Fresh Ricotta

description: Unless you’re familiar with coffee concentrate, New Orleans iced coffee is a puzzling ritual. The first time I had it, I watched skeptically as a friend’s mother filled a plastic Mardi Gras cup with ice, poured in an inch of inky coffee from a mayonnaise jar, then topped it off with milk. It was as smooth as a milkshake but had a rich coffee flavor and packed a caffeinated punch. It was easily the best iced coffee I’d ever had, yet another thing that tastes better in New Orleans.
title: New Orleans Cold Drip Coffee
Yogurt and Lemon Granita With Mastic
Whiting Stew With White Beans, Butternut Squash and Chorizo
Tim McNulty's Blackened Hake Fillets With Roasted Red Pepper Sauce
Sopa Seca de Calamares (Squid and Tortilla Casserole)
Muffuletta
description: Here is The Times's take on a classic New Orleans sandwich, built between slices of light, airy sesame bread, and layered thick with olive salad and cold cuts. It is among the best picnic sandwiches on the planet.

It isn't easy to cook chicken so that its skin is crisp and its interior juicy. Grilling, roasting and sauteing all have their problems. But there is an effective and easy method for getting it right, using two ovenproof skillets. A split chicken is placed in one of them, skin side down. The other skillet goes on top as a weight, which helps retain moisture and insures thorough browning. A couple of clean rocks or bricks can be used instead of the second skillet. (If the weight of choice doesn't seem terribly pristine, it can be wrapped in foil.)
title: Chicken Under A Brick
Soft-Shell Crabs With Fennel and Thyme
Piquillo Peppers Stuffed With Shiitake Mushrooms And Spinach
Shrimp Burgers
ingredients: peeled shrimp, deveined if you like

title: Pot-Roasted Pork With Apples, Potatoes And Celery Root
Mexican-Style Pot Roast With Raisins And Almonds
Roasted Garlic
recipe_yield: About a half-pound of roast garlic

title: Fatty Crab's Chili Crab
description: Matt Lee and Ted Lee snatched this recipe for chili crab from chef Zakary Pelaccio before the first Fatty Crab opened in New York. There are now locations in St. John and Hong Kong. With the restaurant, Pelaccio pays homage to a crab joint he frequented during a seven-month cooking stint in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. This recipe calls for blue crabs and spices them up with chili sauce, garlic and ginger among much else. Serve with crab picks, cold beer and many napkins.

title: Char Kway Teow
description: This stir-fry noodle dish, char kway teow, was inspired by one served at a crab restaurant in Kuala Lumpur frequented by the chef Zakary Pelaccio.

title: Light Potato Salad
description: I know the potato salad I suggest is in culinary terms very un-American. I resolutely believe, however, that potatoes are so much better dressed in oil and vinegar (but it must be good wine vinegar) than blanketed in mayonnaise.

title: Chilled Zucchini Bisque with Leeks Andlemon
Grilled Corn, Lima Bean And Lobster Ragout
Chicken With Scotch-Bonnet Peppers and Pomegranate-Molasses Jerk Sauce
Pear-Stuffed Pork Roast With Dark-Beer Sauce
Asparagus Salad with Soy-Mustard Dressing
description: There are real differences between skinny and fat asparagus spears, aside from appearance, and it's worth attending to them. With either, you must first break off the woody bottoms (magically, they snap off in pretty much the right place every time), a quick but necessary chore. But it is always worth peeling thick asparagus, from stem to the bottom of the flower bud. The best way to do this is with a vegetable peeler. Lay each spear on a flat surface and give it a few quick strokes.

title: Scallops With Shiitakes, Lemon And Parsley
Rack of Pork Roasted With Sherry and Pears
Pear-Pecan Tart With Maple Ice Cream
Potato, Endive And Hazelnut Chopped Salad
Pea, Asparagus And Arugula Chopped Salad
A Loose Interpretation Of Cobb Salad
Green Bean, White Bean, Basil And Ricotta Chopped Salad
Alek Wek's Okra Soup
recipe_yield: 4 servings for models -- or 2 for hungry mortals

title: Spaghetti With Fresh Tomato and Basil Sauce
description: This recipe came to The Times in 2003 from the chef Scott Conant, who was then cooking at his restaurant L'Impero in Manhattan. It is simple, classic Italian fare that makes the most of summer's tomatoes, but you can also make it with hothouse offerings and it will be delicious.

title: Thomas and Cheryl Etheredge's Beef Brisket
description: This recipe requires an oven with a top broiler.

title: Hot Cheese Olives
description: This is classic 1950s cocktail fare that, unlike the savory gelées and boiled ham canapés that are best forgotten, we still want to eat today. Just wrap cocktail olives in a simple cheddar cheese dough and bake until golden. Martini optional.

title: Lobster Ravioli In Won Ton With Lemon-Grass Butter Sauce
recipe_yield: 7 servings of 2 ravioli each as a first course

title: Salad of Spiced Lamb, Rice Vermicelli, Coriander and Holy Basil
La Paloma
ingredients: Herradura Hacienda del Cristero Blanco tequila

description: If meat is involved, you can find me covering it in flavor-enhancing tenderizing liquids before grilling, broiling, baking or roasting it. The more you do to the meat before you cook it, the less you have to do during or after. In this case apple juice or cider gives tang and wards off stringiness, a small amount of oil keeps things juicy and maple syrup, soy, star anise, cinnamon and garlic impart deep, luscious flavor. These two meats work well in conjunction: the relatively lean chicken is enhanced in taste and texture by the pork ribs, which give off flavorsome fat as they roast. You can use whatever ribs you like; meaty ones are best, but as long as the ribs are separated, rather than in a slab, they'll do just fine. As for the chicken, I implore you to use thighs, bone-in, skin-on because the meat is more tender and the taste infinitely better.
title: Maple Chicken 'n' Ribs
Eva Bone's Sour-Cream Poundcake With Strawberries
Sea Bass Fillets with Mushroom Beurre Noisette
Sesame-Crusted Fish With Butter and Ginger Sauce
description: This recipe came out of a 2005 kitchen

title: Whole Fish in Fennel
description: Grilling fish is not daunting when you master a few details, like selecting the right type of fish, keeping your grill clean and — the moment of truth — knowing how to turn. A whole fish can simply be rolled over: make sure you have room on the grill to achieve this. For a very large fish, like a seven-pound wild striped bass, you will need to shovel two spatulas under it, then roll it.

ingredients: Salt and freshly ground black pepper
title: Halibut with Indian Rub and Corn Salsa

description: The chef Zak Pelaccio went deep on the ubiquitous Cubano, and came up with this voluptuous, assertive sandwich of velvet-tender pork, salty cheese and crunchy, fiery bites of pickled jalapeño. It takes some time to make and assemble all the ingredients, but a fair amount of it can be done ahead of time and the result, served for a weekend dinner or afternoon feast, is deeply complex and endlessly delicious.
title: 5 Ninth's Cubano
Mussels in White Wine and Crème Fraîche
recipe_yield: 4 servings as an appetizer, 2 as a main dish

title: Sweet or Salty Limeade or Lemonade
Brandade of Cod With Langoustines and Gazpacho Sauce
Gordon Ramsay's Sea Bass With Vanilla-Bean Foam
The Square's Roast Halibut With Crab and Iceberg Lettuce
Sauteed Black Sea Bass With Sweet Red Pepper
Acorn Squash With Polenta Souffle And Pulled Pork
Schrafft's Lobster Thermidor
description: In this French dish, the meat of the lobster is cooked in a creamy mustard sauce then returned to its shell for baking. This recipe is adapted from the version that was served at Schrafft's, an upscale chain of restaurants popular in the northeast in the first half of the twentieth century.

title: Timothy Maxson's Oyster And Chanterelle Pudding
Cucumber Salad With Scallops
ingredients: mint, cilantro, basil or a combination

title: Fresh Tomato Sauce With Olives and Basil
Baked Tomatoes Stuffed With Bulgur, Feta and Raisins
recipe_yield: Four main-dish servings or eight side-dish servings

title: Marinated Asparagus And Yellow Pear Tomatoes
Pavlova With Mango Puree And Berries
Craig Claiborne's Fried Chicken
description: This fried chicken is classic Mississippi picnic fare, and goes hand in hand with a cold repast of deviled eggs, coleslaw and frosty drinks. A well-seasoned cast iron pan is best for cooking it, but you can do all that work the day before your feast. Drain it on a paper bag and cover it tightly with plastic wrap. It will keep until you unpack the basket. (The New York Times)

title: The Silver Palate's Chocolate Cake
description: This recipe is adapted from “The Silver Palate Cookbook,” written by Sheila Lukins and Julee Rosso, who through their store in Manhattan, the Silver Palate, introduced bisteeya and poppy-seed dressing to the Upper West Side. For many, their cookbook, originally published in 1982, was a book of revelations: even if you hadn’t mastered the art of French cooking, a meal of chicken Marbella and an indulgent dessert, cooked with confidence, was not beyond your grasp. Enter this decadent chocolate cake, whose title belies its incredible simplicity. The ingredients take hardly any time to whip together, and it bakes in a tube pan for under an hour. Gild it with a gooey chocolate frosting, and feed it to those you love with good cheer.

title: Chicken Waterzooi
description: Waterzooi, a wine-deep Belgian stew originally made with fish, but more recently of chicken, was one of Julia Child’s favorite dishes, first taught to her in Paris by the chef Max Bugnard. She gave the recipe to The New York Times in 1987. It is easy weeknight cooking: the dish can be assembled in the morning before work, or even the night before. Then, in the evening, simmer it for about half an hour, and then use the cooking liquid to make a light but creamy sauce. Serve with potatoes or good bread.

title: Boneless Shell Steak With Crushed Peppercorns
German Oven Pancake
description: Cooking with children requires patience and a deep tolerance for mess. It rewards magic tricks — true transformation of ingredients into something delicious. This recipe delivers, and how, with a pancake that puffs up beautifully as it cooks. You can top as suggested with warm applesauce, jam or maple syrup, or try fresh fruit and whipped cream instead. It’s a child-friendly recipe that will last for decades.
This dense, moist cake is a great baking project for children. Cooking with kids requires having a lot of tolerance for mess and a willingness to slow down the process.
title: Wacky Cake
Roast Loin of Pork With Sage
Roast Carrots, Tomatoes And Onions With Thyme
Roast Potatoes With Garlic And Rosemary
Risotto With Artichokes And Fava Beans
Risotto With Peas And Sun-Dried Tomatoes
ingredients: Coarse salt and freshly ground pepper

title: The Minimalist’s Soupe au Pistou
description: One of my favorite dishes to make with fresh basil is soupe au pistou, the Provençal creation that combines legumes, vegetables and a strong but pared-down version of pesto (no more than basil, garlic and oil) to produce a gutsy, hearty soup.

title: Red Snapper Stew With Aioli
ingredients: medium tomatoes, peeled, seeded and chopped
red snapper (about 4 fillets), cut into 1-inch strips

title: Salt-Baked Whole Pompano With Parsley Oil
Red Snapper and Star Fruit Soup
Marion Cunningham’s Lemon Pancakes
description: These spectacular pancakes, adapted from a Marion Cunningham recipe, are made with cottage cheese, lemon peel and beaten egg whites, which makes them puff up like a soufflé. You have to whip the egg whites using an electric mixer, so this is definitely a weekend or holiday affair, but goodness, are they ever worth it. Serve with blueberries or raspberries and a dollop of plain yogurt.

title: Steamed Mussels With Lovage
recipe_yield: Serves 2 as a main course, 4 as an appetizer

title: Pasta with tuna, anchovies, pine nuts and currants
recipe_yield: Six first-course or four main-course servings

title: Rabbit salad
recipe_yield: Six first-course or four main-course servings

Spicy Fried Fish Balls
description: While eating in Kuala Lumpur food stalls, Zak Pelaccio, chef of Fatty Crab and 5 Ninth restaurants in Manhattan, first tried otak-otak, an intense, spicy mackerel paste. Although in Malaysia you’d usually find otak-otak steamed, he rolls it into balls and deep-fries them as a cocktail snack for 230 Fifth, a rooftop bar where he consults on the menu.

title: Lobster or Shrimp Salad with Corn and Tomatoes
Bigeye Tuna With Microherbs and Ginger-Apricot Aioli
Skewered Chicken Thighs With Peanut Sauce
Philippe Bertineau's Heirloom Tomato Salad With Farm Goat Cheese
Sauteed Potatoes With Onions and Garlic
Pasta With Walnuts And Olive Oil
recipe_yield: 6 appetizer servings, or 3 to 4 main course servings

title: Braised Picnic Ham With Brussels Sprouts
Creme au Chocolat
description: To make this classic dish a little less rich, I substitute milk for the heavy cream that conventionally serves as its base, combining it with a dash of flour and a little egg to create a light pastry cream, to which I add enough chocolate to make a dark, intensely flavored dessert that can be served with or without cookies. It will keep in the refrigerator for a week or so. Be certain to cover it well with plastic wrap to keep it from absorbing other flavors in the refrigerator.

title: Fresh Mozzarella and Tomato Salad With Sherry Vinaigrette
Poached Salmon With Sauteed Leeks and Leek-Cream Sauce
Curried Chicken and Shrimp With Grapes
Fine Noodles With Sesame Seeds

title: Nancy Linehan's Seafood Chowder
ingredients: Freshly ground white pepper to taste

title: Gina Pfeiffer's Chili
ingredients: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste

title: Helen Kent's Apple Pie With Quince
Florence Fabricant's Penne With Artichokes And Mushrooms
Roast Chicken With Pomegranate Glaze And Fresh Mint
Sliced Oranges With Pomegranate Caramelized Walnuts
Smoked Ricotta
description: At Quince in San Francisco, Michael Tusk, the chef, smokes fresh ricotta over fruitwood and spices until it's lightly browned and crumbly. If you have a stove-top smoker, this is the time to use it, but you can improvise using a wok, a round baking rack and a vegetable steamer. (Fruitwood chips are available at barbecuewood.com.)

title: Coeur à la Creme With Rhubarb Sauce
description: This recipe is from my friend Narcissa Titman, who got it from her friend Betty Kramer; Betty no longer recalls where she discovered it. I added the rhubarb sauce. If you don't have heart molds, just use a wide, shallow sieve.

title: Pineapple Upside-Down Cake
description: In this country, ingestion of the pineapple upside-down cake has often been used as proof of citizenship – unless you had some as a child, you simply weren't an American. I've had plenty of bad ones -- usually because the dough is too heavy or dry, and sometimes the overly shrill sweetness makes you want to quit living, at least for the length of time you are eating it. But properly prepared, this guilty pleasure is most welcomely retro, and in the recipe here, the cake, while not exactly dietetic, is not life-threatening either.

title: Steamed Fish Fillets With Hard-Cooked Egg Sauce
ingredients: red snapper, grouper, sea bass, or any other firm fillet

title: Pan-Seared Scallops With Cabernet Risotto And Lemon Broth
Roasted New Potatoes and Tomatoes With Lardo
description: Salumi isn't just for sandwiches: Dino Bugica, the executive chef at Taverna Santi in Geyserville, Calif., layers lardo over roasted potatoes and cherry tomatoes for a simple yet rich side dish.

title: Fennel Confit With Kalijira Rice And Olives
Pumpkin, Sage, Chestnut And Bacon Risotto
Bay Scallops With Fennel, Endive And Rosemary-Orange Caramel Glaze
Crispy Chicken Breasts With Spinach-And-Green-Pumpkin-Seed Sauce
Monsoon Salt and Pepper Whole Prawns
North Chinese Roast Eggplant
recipe_yield: Four to six servings as a side dish or salad

title: Basic Corn Chowder
description: This is chowder at its simplest: corn, onion, potatoes and milk, with a couple of chopped tomatoes and a handful of parsley to add flavor and color. Starting with bacon and finishing with cream makes a richer version of the dish. But you could easily expand its borders by adding curry powder and ginger, sour cream and cilantro. Or when the potato is replaced by rice and the cream with coconut milk, Southeast Asian seasonings can be added to make a chowder that has little in common with the original, save for its intense corn flavor.

title: Roasted Pork Tenderloin With Ginger And Golden Raisins
Apple Almond Tart With Gingered Streusel Topping
Basmati Rice With Coconut Milk And Ginger
Brioche Apple Charlotte With Raspberry Sauce
Frankies Spuntino Pork Braciole
description: Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli, who own the Frankies Spuntino restaurants in New York, prefer to keep it mellow. "I cooked on the line for 18 years," Mr. Falcinelli told The Times. Mr. Castronovo, equally low-key, said, "We like to take the easy approach." That means many of their dishes, like vegetable antipasti, grilled meats and wine-stewed prunes, are cooked well ahead and assembled to order or served at room temperature. In this version of braciola, the meat rolls are covered with canned tomatoes that become sauce as the meat cooks. "My grandfather calls it gravy," Mr. Falcinelli said. "For the Sunday sauce, you do spareribs, sausage, meatballs, braciola." The Franks’ version is lighter, meant to be eaten with salad and bread, not steaming pasta. Leftovers are good for sandwiches the following day.

title: Sour-Cream Coffee Cake
description: Here is a classic coffee cake with a tender crumb and a crunchy streusel topping that comes together in about an hour. It's quite rich, so your serving sizes don't need to be large. Be warned: the center does have a tendency to sink a bit as the cake cools, but we think it's a small price to pay for such a moist, delicious cake.

title: Recipes Mixed Greens With Herb-Vinegar Dressing
Goat Cheese With Shallot-Cassis Marmalade
recipe_yield: 4 cheese courses -- with a salad, it could be lunch

title: Curried Roast Chicken, Durban Style
description: In Madhur Jaffrey's book "From Curries to Kebabs: Recipes From the Indian Spice Trail" (Clarkson Potter, 2003), which explores the dispersion of Indian food worldwide, there is a recipe from Durban, South Africa, for chicken roasted whole with a forcefully seasoned ginger and chili paste. The chicken is skinned before seasoning and cooking, not a demanding job but one that requires care. The fragrant heat of the chicken, which stayed moist thanks to its foil cocoon, even seemed to tease some spicy flavors from the Marcel Lapierre Morgon Beaujolais I poured with dinner. The fruitiness of the wine helped tame the heat.

title: Icelandic Lamb Loins
ingredients: D'Artagnan Rich Duck and Veal Stock

title: Fresh Green Peas With Pearl Onions
Veal Milanese
description: On a cold night in the winter of 2000, the formidable food reporter Amanda Hesser went with friends to Caffe Rosso in Greenwich Village. “I was in the mood for veal and red wine,” she wrote in The Times a year later. “When the main courses came, the waiter set down my veal Milanese: a pounded chop as large as a frying pan, crusted with bread crumbs and smothered with a glistening mess of arugula and tomatoes. I squeezed lemon over the veal and set about carving. It was just what I was after: the tender meat was pounded paper-thin with fat on the edges and a thin, pebbly coating of bread crumbs. The peppery salad and lemon offered steady relief. But it left me with a single thought: to come back in the summer when arugula and tomatoes are in season.” Then she gave us a recipe for the dish, perfect for summer, when arugula and tomatoes are in season. Go to!

title: Cold Veal Soup With Salsa Verde
Fresh Fettuccine With Butter, Peas and Sage Sauce
Shell Beans With Mushroom and Parsley Pesto
Shanghai-Style Vegetable Noodles
ingredients: Freshly ground white pepper to taste

Sea Bass Baked In A Salt Crust

Sauteed Asparagus With Fleur De Sel
Pappardelle And Shiitake Mushrooms In Saffron Cream Sauce
Single Malt Whisky, Crystallized Ginger And Pecan Ice Cream
The Original Mix Classic Bloody Mary (a k a the Red Snapper)
Oven-Roasted Wild Mushrooms With Goat Cheese And Chili Oil
Carrot Top Cake
description: Renee Allen Mancino, the owner of the Carrot Top Pastries with locations in Inwood and Washington Heights in Manhattan, gave The New York Times this recipe for her beloved carrot cake. Her tips: California carrots are best; carrots grated too far ahead of time won’t give a cake proper moisture; vegetable oil bakes more evenly in the batter than butter. Go to!

title: Rozanne Gold's Watermelon And Feta Salad
Carole Peck's Apricot, Bok Choy and Mint Salad
