Spaghetti With Slow-Roasted Tomatoes and Cheese
Roasted Atlantic Salmon With Savoy Cabbage
Naked Tofu With Cold Sesame Soba Noodles
Barbara Kafka's Sorrel Soup
ingredients: sorrel leaves, cut crosswise into thin strips (2 cups)

title: Fettuccine With Tomato And Lovage Sauce
Lamb and Rice With Olives and Dried Cherries
Apple-and-Bread Dumplings in Juniper-Scented Chicken Broth
Diane Judge's New England Boiled Dinner
Maine Coast Lobster Rolls
description: Here is the simplest of recipes, brought to The Times in 2001 by Jason Epstein in the low, dispiriting weeks that followed the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. He was inspired, he wrote, by the food writer M.F.K. Fisher’s account of a disastrous love affair, and quoted her in his article about cooking for friends at that time: “We returned to the life that had been so real, like fog or smoke, caught in the current of air. We were two ghosts [but] very live ghosts, and drank and ate and saw and felt and made love better than ever before, with an intensity that seemed to detach us utterly from life.” Thus, of course, lobster rolls.

title: Warm White-Bean And Scallop Salad With Spicy Tomato Glaze
Stuffed Chicken Breasts Poached In Tomato Consomme
Roasted Pork With Carrot Glaze, Polenta And Green Beans
Tomato Relish
description: 10 minutes

title: Elaine’s Fettuccine Alfredo
description: This recipe came to The Times in a 2004 article about Elaine Kaufman, the founder and proprietress of the famed New York restaurant and celebrity hot spot that bore her name and where this dish was served. There is nothing fancy or complicated about it – it's glorified macaroni and cheese, really – but it is delicious and deeply satisfying. (Fun fact: Jackie O was a fan.)

title: Montpelier Butter
description: "One of my favorite recipes in the whole book ('Jeremiah Tower Cooks') is for Montpelier butter -- it's the best version I've ever tried and incredibly versatile. In 'New American Classics,' Tower wrote that this classic compound butter 'transforms hot cauliflower' and that 'on top of mashed potatoes it is so good that it should be arrested.' Here he says he hasn't changed his mind and further recommends it with hot grilled fish or steaks and, at room temperature, with cold poached salmon. With typical passion, he adds that when it is spooned between slices of leftover roast pork or veal 'the slices reassembled, left for a day, and then eaten at cool room temperature, it creates a lifelong memory.'"

title: Alice Waters's Tuna Nicoise
ingredients: fresh grilled tuna, flaked into large pieces
small potatoes, cooked, peeled and sliced

title: Tofu And Onions In Caramel Sauce
Mousse of Peppers With Anchovy Sauce
Fish Soup
description: Ms. Hodgson brought us this recipe over 20 years ago in an article that extolled the virtues of halibut, and indeed, it is very good fish for soups. Here, fish and shellfish are briefly cooked in a saffron-flavored broth.

title: Chicken Noodle Soup for One
description: Home alone? This is a superfast soup that is meant to feed one person — that’s right, one. Soy sauce, sherry and ginger give tang and heat to the broth, and udon noodles lend a decidedly Asian feel. And with the added flavors of chicken, spinach and sugar-snap peas, it’s healthy and filling.

title: Potato Hash With a Fried Egg
description: This potato and onion hash is hearty and no-nonsense, substantial comfort food at its simple best. Although I tend to cook it just for myself at home, I bet if you gave it to a tableful of people when they came round for supper, they would be weepingly grateful, fashionable dietary restrictions notwithstanding. I like a little Tabasco sprinkled over the egg.

title: Tiny Pancakes For Caviar
description: Eating caviar in a restaurant or supplying it for a group of people is extravagant to the point of recklessness. Buying a small tin and demolishing it entirely yourself is hedonistic heaven. I love these pancakes with caviar. Unlike regular blini, they do not need yeast, so they take only a few minutes to rustle up. I think of them as potato pancakes, but actually they use only a little potato starch, not real potatoes. They are very plain and not enormously potatoey, but they are the best carrier imaginable for anything salty. (Try them with sour cream and lox.)

title: Goat Cheese and Potato Cakes With Watercress-and-Endive Salad
Pasta With Red Onion And Mace
Creamed Spinach With Nutmeg And Golden Raisins
Buttermilk-Brown Sugar Waffles
description: This recipe first appeared in The Times in a 2006 article Julia Moskin wrote about wedding registries and what items couples should (and shouldn't) include on theirs. A cookware set? No. Better to buy pieces individually according to a couple's needs. A waffle iron? Why yes, if there's any chance of children.

title: Lentil Soup With Pounded Walnuts and Cream
Pumpkin Panna Cotta
description: When you want a pumpkin dessert, but not the heft of a pie, this light and creamy make-ahead custard will do the trick. It's surprisingly simple to prepare; just combine the ingredients in a saucepan, heat, then strain through a sieve and chill for at least 3 hours. Divine.

title: Fettuccine With Asparagus And Shiitake Mushrooms
Stir-Fried Asparagus, Scallops and Sesame Seeds
Braised Lamb Shanks With White Bean Puree
Salmon Wrapped in Phyllo With Spinach and Cheese
Balsamic Vinegar Sauce
ingredients: medium red onion, peeled and thinly sliced

title: Sea Scallop Sandwiches With Citrus Juices
Sautéed Flounder With Walnut And Garlic Sauce
Salmon With Bacon And Gherkin Dice
Crêpes Suzette
description: This is just one of those desserts that seem, on the page as on the plate, to be labor-intensive and tricky, but in fact are as simple to make as they are gratifying to eat. For one thing, you can make the crepes in advance; they could sit, piled between torn-off sheets of baking parchment and well wrapped in the refrigerator, for a good three days without coming to any harm. But I must admit to taking, more than once, an even quicker route: using good store-bought crepes. Once they're immersed in the sweet orangey syrup, they will not betray their prefabricated origins.
You can make the crepes in advance; they could sit, piled between torn-off sheets of baking parchment and well wrapped in the refrigerator, for a good three days without coming to any harm.
title: Crepes
Pasta With Pea Greens And Squid
description: Watercress can be substituted for the young pea greens or the Oriental specialty can be mail-ordered through Gino Roselli at Balducci's in New York City, (212) 673-2600.

title: Roasted Free-Range Chicken With Swiss Chard And Marrow Gratin
description: Drawing on a classic French technique, this full-flavored chicken with greens is a Baedeker of things to come. For a leaner meal, replace the butter with olive oil in the gratin and eliminate the marrow bones.

title: Coriander-Encrusted Lemon-Grass Tuna
description: Sushi-grade tuna is best for this dish, and the amount of coriander seeds can be increased, up to double the amount, for a stronger flavor. A 1-inch piece of lemon peel can be used if lemon grass is not available.

title: Gratin Of Exotic Fruits
description: Sliced very thin, the pineapple provides a perfect insulation for the more delicate exotic fruits beneath, as well as giving a flat surface for caramelizing the ginger sugar. The result is a guilt-free variation of creme brulee.

title: Oreo Rum Strawberry Pie
description: The pie needs to be chilled several hours or overnight before serving.

title: Chicken With Rice, The Easy Way
Duck Braised with Turnips and Shallots
Odeon's Roast Red Pepper, Tomato and Corn Soup
Alo Alo's Gold and Red Tomato Soup
Paillards Of Chicken With Pepper And Onion Salad
Paillards Of Turkey With Asparagus, Herb And Chili Salad
Curried Paillards Of Pork With Basmati Rice, Apricots And Pistachios
Lamb Chops With Artichoke Mint Salad
Peppered Beef With Watercress And Cucumber Salad
Sesame Crusted Tofu With Spinach And Carrots
Butternut Squash Soup With Goat Cheese and Squash Crostini
Double Veal Chops With Braised Spring Vegetables
Roasted Halibut With Baby Artichokes And Parsley Sauce
Sauteed Fruit And Red Berry Sorbet
Braised Rabbit With Polenta
ingredients: rabbit, 3 1/3 to 4 pounds, cut into 6 to 8 pieces

title: Stone-Ground Grits With Poached Eggs and Shaved Summer Truffle

description: Use organic ingredients where possible.
title: (Save the Polar) Bear Claws
Tartiflette
description: This potato recipe is based on tartiflette, a Savoy dish. Waxy potatoes are simmered with white wine, onion and lardons, then smothered with a heady cheese like reblochon and baked until bubbly and brown. I varied mine, adding thyme and using an aromatic cow's milk cheese, Hooligan, from Cato Corner Farm's stand at the Union Square Greenmarket.

title: Prince Edward Island Lobster With Muscat Beaumes-De-Venise Sauce
Mache or Mesclun With Blue Cheese Dressing
Nicoise Salad With Grilled, Olive-Oil- Marinated Tuna

description: Ana Sortun, the chef at Oleana restaurant in Cambridge, Mass., finished culinary school in Paris in 1988. But the education of her palate wasn't complete, she said, until she apprenticed herself to the Tunisian chef Moncef Meddeb in Boston, then began traveling to Turkey and Greece in the 1990's.
title: Spoon Lamb
Bean and Salt Cod Salad With Arugula and Capers
Nantucket Bay Scallops or Sweet Maine Shrimp Crudo
Henry Clay's Southern Mint Julep
description: In an age devoted to convenience and speed, the julep throws up some major hurdles. Although it contains only three ingredients -- sugar, bourbon and mint -- it requires time and patience to make. The drink requires large quantities of crushed ice. To lay the foundation for the drink, it is first necessary to muddle the sugar with a little bourbon and a few mint leaves. It should be served with two straws and garnished with a nice bush of mint, sprinkled with a little powdered sugar, please. And of course, you'll want to serve your juleps in a silver or pewter mug.

title: Lois Dodd's Fresh Corn And Blueberry Pancakes
recipe_yield: Four to six servings, about 20 three-and-one-half-inch cakes

title: Squash And Sweet Corn With Coriander
recipe_yield: Two main-dish servings; four to six side-dish servings

title: Monika Magee's Old-Fashioned Kohlrabi With Cream Sauce
Salmon Fillets With Sweet Red Pepper Sauce
Codfish Fillet With Parsnip Purée
description: This dish is, in effect, a deconstructed New England codfish cake but made with fresh, not salt, cod and with parsnip purée rather than mashed potato. The flavorings, however, are the same.

title: Steamed Halibut With Rosemary Served With Parsnip Purée
description: In this case do not add ginger to the parsnip purée since the halibut steamed with rosemary will have its own flavoring.

title: Flounder Fillets With Mushrooms and Tomatoes
Twice-Baked Potatoes With Goat Cheese And Tarragon
ingredients: Salt and freshly ground white pepper to taste

title: Soft-Shell Crabs Sauteed In Brown Butter
Choucroute-Style Sauerkraut
recipe_yield: About 7 cups, enough for a lot of hot dogs

title: Chinese Barbecued Spareribs
description: This recipe appeared in The Times in an article by June Owen. In an earlier version of this recipe, Owen recommended first roasting the ribs for 55 minutes in an oven set at 350 degrees. This way, when you finish them on the grill, they will be less likely to char and spoil the lacquered look. The choice is yours. David Myers noted that the ribs would also go well with the cucumber salad and preserved ginger from the salmon recipe that follows. But their best accompaniment is probably just a good cold beer.

The cucumber salad calls for shichimi togarashi, or ''seven-spice blend.'' This spicy mixture usually includes sesame, poppy and hemp seeds, chilies, mandarin orange peel and seaweed. The blend used by David Myers, the chef and owner of Sona in Los Angeles, contains yuzu peel, mustard seeds, Sichuan peppercorns and lemon myrtle.
title: Barbecued Salmon With Preserved Ginger and Cucumbers
Iranian Beet, Plum and Celery Soup with Kubbeh (Meat Dumplings)
Apple, Cranberry and Goat Cheese Salad
Chicken and Parsnip Salad With Roasted Shallot Dressing
Stir-Fried Lamb with Chile, Cumin and Garlic
description: Start with lamb shoulder; leg is not lean or tender enough for this treatment. You can use loin if you prefer, but the dish will cost at least 10 times as much and it won’t be any better. Marinate it dry (or nearly so; I use a little soy sauce, for complexity) for as long as you like — 10 minutes, an hour, a day. The flavor will get a little stronger, though not much.

title: Soft-Shell Crabs in Surrey Bacon Dressing
Pasta With Smithfield Ham, Crab and Shiitakes in Creamy Garlic Sauce
Sauteed Idaho Brook Trout With Orange
Individual Apple Tart With Ice Cream And Caramel Walnuts
recipe_yield: One serving and one pint of ice cream

title: Beet and Watercress Risotto With Pancetta
Skillet Irish Soda Bread Served With Cheddar and Apples
description: Authentic Irish soda bread contains no raisins, butter or eggs. This American version is made with buttermilk, butter, eggs, raisins and sugar. It’s baked in a heavy iron skillet so that the top and bottom crusts become crunchy and browned while the center stays tender and pale, studded with treacly bits of raisins.

title: Hunan Beef With Cumin
description: This fragrant beef stir-fry is an adaptation of one found in Fuchsia Dunlop's “Revolutionary Chinese Cookbook,” whose subject is the food of Sichuan’s less celebrated eastern neighbor, Hunan province. Cumin, a spice rarely used in Chinese cooking, chiles, chile flakes and garlic create a heated yet sophisticated flavor profile.

title: Spaghetti With Zucchini And Mint
ingredients: small zucchini, about a pound, washed, trimmed and cut into slices 1/8 to 1/4 inch thick
spaghetti, linguine or other long pasta

title: Grilled Pork Chops With Glazed Peaches
Florence Fabricant Warm Indian Tomatoes With Spicy Chilies
Broiled Sea Scallops With Orange-Butter Sauce
Curried Rice With Apples and Peas
Ragout of Shrimp, Artichokes and Potatoes
Figs With Duck Prosciutto and Sorrel
Seared Sea Scallop Saganaki With Feta
Steamed Halibut In Borscht With Warm Chive-Horseradish Sauce
Sashimi, Chinese Style
ingredients: skinless salmon, tuna or wild striped-bass fillet, very thinly sliced across the grain

title: Grilled Pork Chops With Blueberry Salsa
Cold Blueberry Soup With Orange-Herb Sorbet
Blueberry Lattice Pie
description: Here's a showstopper of a summer pie if there ever was one. In this recipe that came to The Times in 1995, a generous pile of blueberries is tossed with sugar, cinnamon and orange zest then baked in a butter-shortening crust until the filling is bubbly and the crust golden brown. Don't be intimidated by the lattice top. Just take your time, and do your best. No matter what it looks like, it'll taste delicious.

ingredients: cold unsalted butter, cut into 1/2-inch pieces
heavy cream, plus additional for serving, if desired
title: Blueberry Cobbler
description: This cobbler, which comes from the kitchens of Chez Panisse, prizes the berries above all, using only 1/3 cup of sugar. The dough rounds for the top are placed so they don’t cover all the berries, and the juice from the berries bubbles up around the dough.

title: Cod Strudel With Sauerkraut In Riesling Sauce
Chicken Roasted With Sage and Lemon
Fish With Celery Root, Kale and Mushrooms

description: This punch is made with cachaça, the national spirit of Brazil, made from fermented sugar cane juice. Increased interest in the liquor, and Latin American cuisine, has brought several brands to American bars and liquor stores. Use the one you can find. And drink slowly. It’s strong.
title: Passion Fruit Punch (Poncha Maracujá)
Whipped Feta With Sweet and Hot Peppers
Persian Fried Chicken
description: Here is a fried chicken recipe that is the best kind of weeknight cooking, with ingredients found quickly at most local grocery stores, whirled in a food processor and then left overnight to turn into something delicious the next evening. A yogurt marinade helps tenderize the boneless, skinless chicken thighs, infusing them with saffron and paprika, and a quick frying lends the meat a crispy, minty coating. You can marinate the chicken for 3 hours or overnight, but you set the timetable depending on whatever else is going on. This chicken will adapt. Make one night, finish the next. That’s living.

title: Thick Yogurt With Beets, Garlic and Dill
description: Ana Sortun of Oleana restaurant, in Cambridge, Mass., created a menu based on the traditional cooking of the Eastern Mediterranean, especially Turkey and Greece, with many influences of spice and seasoning from the Arab world. She has created surprising but successful dishes like parsnip hummus; this beet-spiked tzatziki (the Mediterranean's traditional cucumber-yogurt-garlic salad), radish salads and rhubarb compotes.

title: Souffléed Crab-Meat Canapés
recipe_yield: 12 large canapés or 36 small hors d'oeuvres

title: Green Mussels With Mustard-and-Roasted- Pepper Mayonnaise
Roast Pork Chops With Mustard-Seed Crust
Roast Chicken With Lemon and Orange
La Vignarola Roman-Style Spring-Vegetable Stew
recipe_yield: Serves 6 as a side dish or first course

title: Artichokes and Preserved Lemons With Honey and Spices
Summer Pork Stew With Tomatoes And Corn
Chopped Salad of Romaine, Arugula, Dill and Lemon
description: Served with niçoise olives, country bread and slices of feta or aged goat cheese, sprinkled with olive oil and black pepper.

title: Chocolate Amaretto Tofu Mousse With Raspberry Sauce
Roasted Cauliflower With Red Wine-Cabbage Sauce
Broiled Cornish Hens With Spicy Salt
Penne Alla Vodka
description: Penne alla vodka is the perfect recipe for easy entertaining: short pasta is easier to cook in quantity than long strands and the sauce is amusingly retro -- think 1960s Rome, where the dish originated. But it is seriously good.

title: Ricotta and Pine Nut Salad
description: Here is a laid-back, unfussy salad that takes no time to prepare and is a great accompaniment to a summer pasta. It’s also good on its own for lunch.

title: Fried Rice With Peas And Chicken
Sweet Lavender, Maple Syrup And Carrot Ice Milk
Fresh Vegetable Salad
ingredients: red ripe plum tomatoes, peeled and seeded and cut into 1/2-inch cubes

title: Sauteed Cantaloupe With Fleur De Sel
Chocolate Caramel Tart
description: It is hard to believe in this day and age – when salted caramel ice cream is almost as ubiquitous as vanilla – that desserts in which salt plays a starring role was once a newfangled concept. This recipe, an adaptation of one attributed to the pastry chef Claudia Fleming, came to The Times in a 2000 article by Amanda Hesser about the development of that very trend, and it is a perfect example of how it's done right. Layers of silky caramel and dark chocolate ganache topped with a sprinkling of crunchy, snow-white fleur de sel make this an unforgettable combination of flavors and textures.

title: Pasta Kerchief With Poached Egg, French Ham And Brown Butter
Nonna's Pasta With Eggs, Pecorino And Sage
ingredients: Salt and freshly ground black pepper

title: Spaghetti With Fried Eggs And Roasted Peppers
Chicken Breast With Sweet-And-Sour Sherry Sauce
Cornbread
description: This basic recipe is so easy and forgiving that you may find yourself making cornbread as often as your mother made mashed potatoes. Only a few ingredients are pretty much fixed: the salt, the baking powder, cornmeal and flour (you want a little flour for lightness). Other than that, feel free to experiment with bits of cooked bacon, sautéed onions or shallots, chili powder or cumin, chopped chilies or herbs, grated cheese, mashed or puréed beans or fresh, canned or frozen corn. The options are practically endless.

title: Ginger Cucumber Salad With Scallops
ingredients: cucumber, preferably thin Asian or English variety
sea scallops (cut in half through their equators if very large)

title: Roast Chicken Salad
description: Here is a fast, easy salad that will make good use of that leftover chicken in the fridge. It comes together easily and melds bright ingredients into a light, satisfying main fare -- perfect for a lazy summer’s weekend lunch.

title: Fettuccine With Smoked Salmon And Asparagus
Baby Carrots With Cream And Mint
Flourless Chocolate Cake With Halvah Honey Sauce
Brined and Braised Pork Belly and Ribs
Mussels in Green-Apple Broth
ingredients: Granny Smith apple, cored and diced
recipe_yield: 6 appetizer or 3 to 4 main course servings

title: Razor Clams With Smoked Paprika Butter And Hominy
Salad With Salt Cod, Olives, Beans and Romesco Sauce
Grilled Lamb With Lentils and Ginger-Nectarine Sauce
Potato Gnocchi With Lobster And Walnut Butter
ingredients: Salt and freshly ground black pepper

title: Fried Rhubarb Ravioli With Spiced Strawberry Sauce
Foie-Gras-and-Jam Sandwiches
recipe_yield: Hors d'oeuvres for 4 people, age 12 and older

title: Chocolate Dump-It Cake
description: “A couple of years ago, my mother taught me to make her dense but moist chocolate birthday cake. She calls it 'dump-it cake' because you mix all of the ingredients in a pot over medium heat, then dump the batter into a cake pan to bake. For the icing, you melt Nestlé's semisweet-chocolate chips and swirl them together with sour cream. It sounds as if it's straight from the Pillsbury Bake-Off, but it tastes as if it's straight from Payard. Everyone loves it.”

title: Pasta With Yogurt And Caramelized Onions
Osso Buco With Lemon and Sage
Braised Lamb Shanks With White Beans
David Eyre’s Pancake
description: Writing in The Times in 1966, Craig Claiborne described making the acquaintance of this oven-baked pancake as if he had met Grace Kelly: “It was discovered some weeks ago at an informal Sunday brunch in the handsome, Japanese-style home of the David Eyres in Honolulu. With Diamond Head in the distance, a brilliant, palm-ringed sea below and this delicately flavored pancake before us, we seemed to have achieved paradise.” (Life was good if you were a food writer in the 1960s.) Nearly 50 years later, readers are still making the dish, and swooning like Claiborne.

title: Green Bean, Mushroom And Olive Salad
ingredients: Greek, Italian or French black olives

title: Straight-Up Rhubarb Pie
description: This rhubarb pie contains no distractions, like strawberries. The crust is made with shortening. (Butter is fine if you want a French tart, but it's not American pie unless it's made with shortening, the author Anne Dimock said.) The top is marked with 8 razor-thin vents.

title: Nina Simonds's Broiled Halibut With Miso Glaze
Friture
description: For friture, any fish between two and four inches will do, but plump round fish are the best because they cook more evenly than a flatfish and they have more meat on their feathery young bones. A mixture of fish is usually found in friture.

title: Black-and-White Cookies
description: There is no reason to settle for a stale shrink-wrapped cookie from the produce market. This classic New York cookie is easy to make.

title: Julie Sahni's Indian Chickpea Ragout With Vegetables
Creamy Grits With Fontina Fonduta And Mushroom Stew
Grilled Chicken and Asparagus Rice Salad
Chorizo With Sweet Pepper And Onion Stew And Fried Croutons
Spanish French Toast
description: There is French toast, and then there are torrijas, the Spanish version. The origins of both are undoubtedly the same: yet another way to make good use of bread that’s no longer fresh. Though torrijas, like French toast, can be served at breakfast, they can also be a knockout dessert.

title: Corn and Barley Salad on Arugula
Lemon-Basil Risotto With Zucchini and Fava Beans
Slow-Roasted King Salmon With Creamed Cucumbers
Pot-Au-Feu Of Spring Vegetables With Chive Popovers
Spring Chicken With Lime And Coriander
Veal Shanks With Carrots And Coriander
The $250 Cookie Recipe
description: Almost everybody has heard the one about the woman lunching at the Neiman Marcus Cafe in Dallas, who enjoyed the chocolate chip cookies so much that she asked for the recipe. For "only two-fifty," the waitress said, it was hers. But when the credit card bill arrived, the woman found the total near $300. Turns out the recipe cost $250, the story goes. In 1997, after years of enduring the myth, Neiman Marcus came up with a recipe – and gave it out for free. It's a delicious variation on chocolate chip cookies, using ground oatmeal, nuts and adding extra chocolate with a grated Hershey bar (you can use any brand you love).

title: Peggy Knickerbocker's Mussel and Potato Salad
Hoppin' John's Southern Potato Salad
description: Along with burgers and hot dogs, a good potato salad is a quintessential part of a cookout, and this one is a classic. It’s dressed with mayonnaise, mustard and juice from the sweet pickle jar and incorporates fresh herbs for taste and greenery.

title: Stuffed Cabbage Rolls
ingredients: garlic, peeled, crushed and chopped fine (1 tablespoon)
fresh bread crumbs, made from processing 4 to 5 slices of bread (preferably rye) in a food processor

title: Nectarine Pie
description: There’s really really nothing better than fresh fruit pie. Though peach pies are de rigeur in the summer, this one uses nectarines (O.K. you can use fresh peaches, too). This pie also takes a turn away from the traditional with a graham-cracker crust.

title: Grilled Lamb Chops With Mint Chutney
Curried Tomato Sauce For Soft-Cooked Eggs
Mustard And Chive Butter Garnish With Asparagus
Wagon Wheels With Sun-Dried Tomato Sauce
Veal Stew With Endive And Carrot
Shrimp Burgers
description: A shrimp burger is simply a cake of shrimp and seasonings served on a bun, with lettuce, tomato and tartar sauce. These concentrate the sweet essence of shellfish and complement it with semisweet seasonings like parsley, onion and bell peppers. They are easy to prepare, and they bring the warmth of a summer beach picnic indoors.

title: Grilled Salmon And Sweet and Sour Onions
Loin Of Pork Stuffed With Prunes
Salmon en Gelée With Coconut Risotto
Chef Chan's Ma Paul Tofu With Minced Pork
description: At Wu Liang Ye in Manhattan, the Ma Paul Tofu is zippy with flavor, and yet its braised cubes melt creamily. With a little ground pork and leek for texture, the dish is simple to make, once the shopping is done, and comes together quickly. Take care not to overcook the tofu.

title: Nettie's Caramel Pie
ingredients: Triple recipe for Aunt Chick's Egg Meringue

title: Fennel And Orange Compote With Pan-Roasted Pork
Tiger Shrimp With Pineapple and Smoked Bacon
Shrimp and Rice Salad With Pineapple Vinaigrette
Black Sea Bass Fillets Provencal Style
Zucchini With Shallots
description: This simple dish from Pierre Franey is light and delicious. It takes only 15 minutes and would be a great side dish for grilled beef or chicken or for any type of seafood. The bread crumbs added at the end provide excellent texture.

title: Lasagna
description: In 2001, Regina Schrambling went on a week long odyssey in search of the ultimate lasagna recipe. She tested several, and finally found her ideal in a mash-up of recipes from Giuliano Bugialli and Elodia Rigante, both Italian cookbook authors.

title: Chestnut Soup With Armagnac Prunes And Cappuccino Foam
Kale, Sweet Potato And Pasta Soup
Curry of Lamb Breast And Potatoes
Presidential Birthday Cake
description: This is a classic butter layer cake based on a recipe from Seth Greenberg, the master cake maker and the son of the founder of William Greenberg Jr. Desserts and Cafes, in Washington. He spent two days baking a $4,000 version of this cake for President Clinton's birthday in 1996.

title: Shirred Farm Eggs with Roasted Small Heirloom Tomatoes
Mark Bittman’s Grilled Eggplant Salad With Yogurt
description: This dish is a creamy and mild eggplant salad made with a quick dressing of yogurt and seasonings. You can grill the eggplant half an hour before you serve the salad, or a half a day (or longer) ahead; it doesn't matter much at all.

title: Takeout-Style Sesame Noodles
description: Eddie Schoenfeld, the affable yarn-spinner and restaurateur who opened Red Farm in the West Village and on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, is also one of New York's finest practitioners of Chinese cuisine. In 2007, he helped The Times drill down into the taste history of sesame noodles in America, and specifically to the ones made and sold by Shorty Tang at the restaurant Hwa Yuan on East Broadway. Soft and luxurious, bathed in an emulsified mixture of sesame paste and peanut butter, rendered vivid and fiery by chili oil and sweetened by sugar, then cut by vinegar, this version brings home what used to be classic New York takeout. “The art is in the balance,” Mr. Schoenfeld said at the time, “between the salt and sweet, the sweet and the fire, and the fire and the acidity.”

title: Ariane Daguin's French Kisses and Gascogne Sushi
Ragout of Clam, Hominy, Squash and Lima Bean
Lamb With Red Wine And Dried Cherries
Squash And Chipotle Chili With Black Beans And Hominy
Creamy White Bean Soup With Bacalao And Piquillo Peppers
Spanish Olive Oil Cake With Kumquats And Toasted Almonds
Polenta With Tomato And Wild Mushroom Sauce
Corn and Yellow Tomato Risotto With Shrimp
Strawberry Fool
description: This Minimalist recipe is as basic as dessert gets, and especially in strawberry season it’s just perfect. It is essentially fresh strawberries and whipped cream (substitute heavy cream, sour cream or yogurt). It can be eaten right away or refrigerated. Only a fool would pass this up.

title: Turkey Scaloppine With Prosciutto and Cheese
Littleneck Clams Steamed In Green Chili-Coconut Milk Broth
Black and Green Olives With Celery
Grilled Flank Steak With Kimchi-Style Coleslaw
Herb Polenta With Red Bell Pepper Sauce
Grilled Or Pan-Grilled Steak With Chipotle, Bacon And Tomatoes
Gorgonzola Cream Sauce With Angel-Hair Pasta
Fish Stock
ingredients: heads and bones from white-fleshed fish, like snapper, bass or cod

title: Roast Chicken With Onions And Parsley
Classic Prime Rib For A Small Crowd
Grilled Snapper With Lemon Basil Beurre Blanc
Chicken Breasts In Foil With Sun-Dried Tomatoes And Olives
Fresh Corn Risotto With Basil, Tomato And Lime
Fast, Creamy Chicken Curry
description: A blended curry powder is one of the original convenience foods, a venerable spice rub that can improve the flavor of almost anything. Even a good chicken breast is about as bland as meat can get, but spiced with a little curry, its flavor comes alive. In this dish, season sliced onions and chicken breast with the spice and finish the sauce with yogurt or sour cream. The process is streamlined so that it takes no more than 15 minutes. (Begin cooking white rice, the natural accompaniment, before cutting the onion.)

title: Roast Bone Marrow and Parsley Salad
description: Spread onto toast with a spoonful of the parsley salad, the marrow is warm and fat and spiky from the peppery greens.

title: Chicken Strips With Rice, Oranges And Dried Cherries
Grilled Or Roast Salmon With Salsa Fresca
Sea Scallops With Sugar Snap Peas
Strawberry Pavlova
description: The particular joy of this dreamy dessert, which was named in honor of the Russian ballerina, is that the meringue base can be made in advance. Then to serve it, drizzle the strawberries with a little balsamic vinegar and vanilla (a combination that brings out the fullest essential flavor of the fruit), whip some cream and arrange it all on a plate. It’s magnificent, and deliriously easy.

title: Shredded Potato Cake With Egg And Cheese And Bacon
Vegetarian Dagwood
description: This sandwich takes advantage of late-summer’s bounty, with a pile of vegetables set between two layers of focaccia. It takes about half an hour to prepare. You’ll glaze some sliced onions with garlic, lemon and olive oil, chop and sauté the vegetables you happen to have on hand, and then layer it all with slices of your best tomatoes, some cheese and chopped olives. A smear of mayonnaise helps stick the whole thing together.

title: Sauerkraut, Beet And Cucumber Roll-Up With Walnuts
ingredients: fresh jarred sauerkraut, rinsed and well drained

title: Lobster Salad With Avocado And Hearts Of Palm
Paula Gabriel's Persian Rice With Tah Dig Crust
Pasta With Zucchini, Shrimp and Saffron
Zucchini Cake With Ginger and Hazelnuts
Green Mango Salad With Salty-Sweet Grilled Steak
Bulgur Salad With Pomegranate Dressing and Toasted Nuts
Crispy Shredded Okra With Tomato and Lemon
Ruby Chard Stems And Anchovy Saute
Dough For Pissaladiere Or Tarte Flambee
recipe_yield: Enough dough for 2 pizzas, each about 12 inches

title: Salmon With New Potatoes and Dill
Red Snapper With Hot Pepper and Cilantro

ingredients: Granny Smith apple, peeled and sliced 1/4-inch thick
title: Goat Cheese and Apple Omelet
description: This omelet of green apples and goat cheese is an unusual pairing -- at least in the omelet world -- but a wonderful one from Garrett Oliver, the brewmaster of Brooklyn Brewery. On the day we made this recipe, he paired the dish with a glass of Blanche de Chambly, a Belgian-style wheat beer made in Canada.

title: Pasta With Lobster, Chorizo and Peas
Spicy Crab Cakes
description: This recipe came to us by way of Garrett Oliver, the brewmaster of Brooklyn Brewery. He believes beer and wine should always be served with food. And beer, he contends, is often the better choice.

title: Ginseng Tea
description: Ginseng is believed by the Chinese to brighten the eyes, enlighten the mind and increase wisdom. Western medicine will only concede the eye part, although a cup of ginseng tea when you're feeling low can be so restorative that you might believe the East is on to something.

title: Viva! Health Tonic
description: Robert A. Barnett, author of ''Tonics, More Than 100 Recipes That Improve the Body and the Mind,'' defines a tonic as a food, an herb or a thought that improves your well-being. In traditional Chinese medicine, tonics are used to enhance immunity, with specific herbs prescribed for specific problems. In Europe, tonics are given to stimulate digestion, while here in the West, Barnett says, we think of them as anything that you put in your mouth that makes you feel better.

title: Savory Melon Salad in Honeydew Vinaigrette
Crescents of Melon on Fresh Ricotta
Honeydew Sorbet With Vanilla And Honey
Crenshaw Soup
ingredients: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste

title: Taramosalata
recipe_yield: About 8 cups. (Send some home with all your guests!)

title: Chicken Paillards With Fennel, Red Pepper and Apricot Salad
Braciola Steaks Stuffed With Cheese And Prosciutto
Veal Scaloppine With Hazelnuts and Balsamic Vinegar
Turkey Scaloppine With Apples and Tamari
Warm Clam Salad With Fresh Herbs And Tomatoes
Skewered Grilled Fruit With Ginger Syrup
description: This is a melange of quickly grilled fruit, brushed with a ginger sauce that itself takes about five minutes to put together. The sauce is a simple sugar syrup -- half sugar, half water, boiled together until the sugar melts -- and is infused with a lot of ginger. You could use other flavors instead (mint, lemon verbena, thyme, even chili), but ginger seems perfect to me.

title: Aromatic Pork In Cold Vegetable Sauce
Sardine Sauce
ingredients: oil-packed sardines, drained and lightly crushed
green peppercorns packed in brine, rinsed

title: Enriched Vinaigrette
ingredients: flat-leaf parsley, leaves only, coarsely chopped

title: Braised Duck With Green Beans, Thai Style
Sea Parsley Salad With Rice Wine Vinaigrette
Steamed Lobsters With Sea Parsley And New Potatoes
Avocado, Grapefruit And Grilled Shrimp Salad
Roasted Ripe Tomato Salsa
description: With two types of tomatoes – standard Jersey and plum – this salsa takes full advantage of summer's bounty. Herbes de Provence and shallots stand in for the traditional seasonings of cilantro and onions, which means it skews slightly, and delightfully, French. We like it with grilled fish or chicken.

title: Ragout Of Spring Vegetables With Morels
Caldo de Pescado a la Celia Cruz (Fish Soup)
Baked Whitefish With Sweet Potatoes
ingredients: Coarse salt and freshly ground pepper

title: Baked Whole Fish With Tahini Marinade
Broiled Coho Salmon With Parsnips Dauphinoise
Skewered Swordfish And Zucchini (From Louisa Hargrave)
Cold Thai Daikon And Shrimp Soup
Migas Eggs A La Mike Marks
Pan Bagna
recipe_yield: One large (1 pound) bread loaf, about 6 servings

title: Chicken legs stuffed with wild rice and mushrooms
Nantucket Bay Scallops With Passion Fruit
Bearnaise Sauce
description: Porterhouse steaks and bearnaise sauce seem to have a natural affinity, with the sauce's tarragon taste playing off the meat's texture. Sop up the rest of this tangy concoction with potatoes and a crusty baguette, and you’ve got a steakhouse meal at home. A word of warning: really watch your heat with this, or your egg yolks will curdle, ruining everything.

title: Grilled Chicken Breast And Bean Salad
Mashed Potatoes and Carrots With Ricotta
Bucatini all’Amatriciana
description: This recipe was brought to The Times by Regina Schrambling in a 1989 article about a return to simple Italian food after an almost decade long obsession with culinary excess and exotica (goose prosciutto, anyone?). This version of the classic pasta dish is an adaptation of a one from Giuliano Bugialli, an Italian cookbook author and cooking teacher. It is simple to prepare – 45 minutes from start to finish -– but full of bright, sophisticated flavors. If you can't get your hands on bucatini or perciatelli, spaghetti will do just fine.

title: Steak and Potatoes Our Way, With Salad
Golden Gazpacho With Serrano Chilies And Scallops
Spaghettini and Mussels With Green Sauce
Marian Burros's Risotto With Wild Mushrooms
Fethi Solak's Eggplant With Meat and Rice
Shad and Shad Roe With Lemon Shallot Butter Sauce
Poached Fish And Vegetables With Garlic Mayonnaise
Brotchan Roy
description: Brotchan roy, a thick broth, is an old Dublin favorite traditionally served with Irish soda bread.

title: Mixed Green Salad With Blue Cheese Dressing
Pickled Swiss Chard Stems
recipe_yield: 6 or more servings as a condiment or in salad

title: Warm Porcini Salad With Mesclun and Black-Truffle Vinaigrette
Grilled Steak With Roquefort Sauce
ingredients: Salt and freshly ground black pepper

title: Chicken-Udon Soup With Hijiki and Spinach Leaves
Warm Chicken-and-Frisee Salad With Bacon Vinaigrette
Goat Cheese Gnocchi With Caramelized Onion And Thyme
Carol Field's Fava Puree With Wild Greens
Seared Sea Scallops With Fresh Fava Bean Puree and Shiitake Mushrooms
Blackberry-Lemon Tart With Champagne- Mint Granite
Minestra Alla Milanese (Vegetable Soup With Rice and Saffron)
Pasta e Fagioli "Harry's Bar" (Bean Soup With Noodles)
Tomatoes With Gorgonzola
recipe_yield: 4 to 6 servings as an appetizer or side dish

title: Fish Fillets With Lemon Turmeric Sauce
Red Snapper Fillets With Thyme and Yellow Pepper
Molly O'Neill's Hot and Sour Soup
Congee With Napa Cabbage
description: The American who wishes to cook Chinese food at home must understand what the Chinese-food scholar Barbara Tropp calls the subliminal role of yin (that which is feminine, dark and yielding) and yang (that which is masculine, bright and hard).

title: Mexican Rice
description: Diana Kennedy, the doyenne of Mexican cooking, has documented that country's technique for simmering one-pot meals from short-grain rice. Her recipe is a basic spice dish, endlessly amenable to different ingredients and moods.

title: Rice With Andouille And Kale
description: Rather than a mere afterthought -- a sad spoonful of white on a dinner plate -- rice is now rivaling pasta as both backbone and canvas for a main dish. This recipe riffs on a basic dish from Diana Kennedy, the doyenne of Mexican cooking, who has documented that country's technique for simmering one-pot meals from short-grain rice. Her

title: Rice With Roasted Butternut Squash, Onions And Sage
Rice With Roasted Peppers And Beans
Spicy Rice With Pork And Tomatillos
Vanilla Bean Poundcake With Muscat-Macerated Fruit
Curried Tofu With Soy Sauce
description: Tofu is light, so I wanted to make the sauce as substantial as possible. Use canned coconut milk with the caramelized onions. Like heavy cream, coconut milk will thicken a sauce, making it luxurious in almost no time. Then, to add contrasting texture, I decided to use nuts as well. Both walnuts and cashews do splendidly here. But the bottom line is the onions: they really must be browned carefully and thoroughly, without burning. (Sam Sifton)

title: Mussel Soup in the Mediterranean Style
Yogurt Soup With Poached Chicken Rissoles
Syrup Of Grains Of Paradise And Rosemary
Pan-Roasted Cod Seasoned With Grains Of Paradise
Simple Nuoc Cham
description: This is the basic sauce that almost always appears on the Vietnamese table, where it serves somewhat the same function as salt and pepper in the West. Nuoc cham is frequently presented in individual saucers and diners dip their food in the sauce before eating it.

title: Ba-Nam's Nem Nuong With Nuoc Leo Sauce
Chef Huy's Banh Tap (Spiced pork on shrimp crackers)
Chef Huy's Chicken With Lemon Grass
Ca Chien Sot Ca (Fried fish with tomato sauce)
Chinese Chicken in the Pot (Variation on Shabu Shabu)
Honey-Glazed Pear Upside-Down Cake
description: This delightful cake emerges from the oven as golden as a pear tarte Tatin, but with a moist, cake-y layer that sops up all of the luscious pear drippings. Let the oohs and aahs begin.

title: Strawberry Basil Margarita
description: The house drink at Dos Caminos

title: Orzo With Basil And Pine Nuts
Chicken Soup With Tiny Veal Meatballs
Baked Rice With Yellow Squash and Red Pepper
Fillet of Beef In Red Wine Sauce
Clams in Black Bean Sauce
description: To most Americans, clams rank just below apple pie in any list of typically American foods, so it may come as a surprise to find that Chinese living in coastal areas, who have never heard of clam chowder, eat and enjoy clams. Here, clams are cooked with black beans, a favorite Chinese accompaniment for seafood.

title: Duck Sauce
description: The name "duck sauce" was created in the United States because this sauce was originally served with deep-fried pressed duck, which had no sauce of its own. Duck sauce became popular as a dip for any food — from spareribs and egg rolls to almost anything else imaginable. There are so many versions of duck sauce that it is hard to decide which kind to make. However, I have created and tested the following, which I feel produces the best taste:

title: Raspberry-Champagne Soup With Rosemary- Raspberry Sorbet
Pan-Seared Duck Breasts With Raspberry Sauce
Mellow Lamb Steaks
description: Buy lamb steaks if you can -- though if you want to tack a bit, duck breasts also work quite well. While the garlic is poaching in its pan, fry the steaks in a scant amount of olive oil until they are flavor-sealed and heat-darkened outside, but still juicily tender within.

title: Linguine With Fresh Salmon and Pesto Sauce
Pan-Bagnat (A Mediterranean Sandwich With Salade Nicoise)
Tower Of Bagel Sandwiches
description: At Eli Zabar's E.A.T. in New York, the smoked salmon and cream cheese sandwich is taken to the next level, literally. The bagel is sliced into four neat slivers that each receive a smear of cream cheese and a slice of salmon before being stacked on top of one another.

title: Braised Lamb With Garlic And Cinnamon
Cold Bisque Of Tomato and Sorrel
Peshe en Saltsa (Fish in Rhubarb Sauce)

description: Lucas Schoorman, a Chelsea art dealer and hobbyist baker, introduced this elegant lemon tart to the Times in 2004. It's a showstopper dessert featuring two distinct, delicious layers: one of frangipani, an almond-rich custard, and another of shimmering lemon confit scattered with slices of lemon. It is mellow and barely sweet, rich and deep, with none of the attack of so many lemon desserts.
title: Lucas Schoormans’s Lemon Tart

Hollandaise Sauce
description: Hollandaise sauce, that staple of brunch, is a classic accompaniment to eggs benedict and steamed asparagus. It is a “mother sauce,” one of the five classic French sauces that provide the base for so many others. Master it and you’ve added a versatile weapon and technique to your culinary arsenal. As with bearnaise sauce and beurre blanc, keep an eye on your heat, and serve the sauce warm, not hot.

title: Civet de lievre marine (Marinated hare stew)
description: The hare should be marinated for 12 to 24 hours, but no more. If marinated for more than 24 hours, it will lose its freshness. The dish can be prepared several days ahead and reheated just before serving. Use a young hare that weighs no more than six pounds.

title: Baked apples, stuffed with beets, pine nuts and raisins
description: This side dish combines several of the usual game accompaniments in a single, attractive presentation. Mr. Lenotre likes to use the Reines des reinettes, but both Granny Smith and Golden Delicious apples may be substituted. He serves it as a side dish to the civet de lievre but it also goes well with pork, duck or turkey.

title: Stuffed Pheasant Breasts With Wild-Mushroom Sauce
description: This dish is named for Gaston Lenotre's hunting lodge, Les Bastes, in Sennely, France. Though the recipe is long and appears complicated, much of the work can be done rather quickly ahead of time.

title: Cooked fresh figs
description: The preparation may be done several hours in advance, then completed at the last minute.

title: Roast Veal With Rosemary and Potatoes
Oeufs A La Neige (Snow Eggs)
description: To prepare this specialty, you make a sweetened milk bath on which you cook oval-shaped meringues that, in theory, resemble eggs. After the so-called eggs are cooked, you combine what is left of the milk with egg yolks and prepare an English custard, or what the French choose to call a sauce anglaise. This is chilled and the eggs are floated on top. The snow-white eggs are served with a vanilla-flavored custard.

Blueberry Crumb Cake
description: For weekend entertaining, planning a menu that can be made in large quantities is essential. A host expecting weekend guests should shop ahead and, well before guests arrive, prepare the recipes that will keep, saving the most perishable for the last minute. Take this cake that Molly O’Neill brought into The Times in 1993, a confection that can play dessert as well as breakfast. As a dessert, slices of the cake can be garnished with whipped cream, a compote of fresh berries or ice cream. For breakfast, slices can be toasted and served with butter, fresh ricotta or marscapone, or warmed in the oven and served with fresh fruit.

title: Grilled Goat's Cheese And Eggplant, From Chris Cox
Fish Pie
description: To the uninitiated, fish pie has an uninviting name and reputation. But this is fish that is gently poached, then swathed in a white sauce and topped with buttery mashed potatoes and finished to a heat-bronzed finish in the oven. It is a dish good for children, but can be made into unapologetic dinner-party fare by poaching the fish in a little white wine, making the white sauce with light cream rather than milk and infusing all of it with the eggy-lemony kiss of saffron. It’s an hour well worth spending.
